Musty Dusty Words for National Old Stuff.list_brief_description: While the origins of this day are hard to trace and it's unclear how many observers actually celebrate this March 2 event , we thought it was a perfectly valid ...

antique.word_example: Ms. Stroh’s father spent millions on  antiques and collectibles, like rare cameras and guitars.
antique.word_definition: made in or typical of earlier times and valued for its age

ancient.word_example: “For me, I think the real passion is with the  ancient coins,” Borland says.

relic.word_example: The loft where his small team works is filled with  relics from his days fronting the pioneering rock group Talking Heads.

vintage.word_example: Indeed, there it was in all its mint-green glory,  vintage bicycles lined up outside the double doors to add character.

anachronism.word_example: That makes the traditional cable box somewhat of an  anachronism.
anachronism.word_definition: something located at a time when it could not have existed

provenance.word_example: Decades after its discovery by Louis Leakey in 1932, the fossil’s antiquity and  provenance have remained in dispute, along with the medical diagnosis.
provenance.word_definition: where something originated or was nurtured

nostalgia.word_example: Nostalgia also in the collection of Harry Truman memorabilia that filled the parlor of the century-old house where I stayed during my visit.

souvenir.word_example: The house produced many  souvenirs of early New York when its owners, Martin Sheridan and Richard Hayman, dug up the basement.

memorabilia.word_example: Across from us is a dusty shelf filled with  memorabilia.
memorabilia.word_definition: a record of things worth remembering

musty.word_example: Finally, in a pitch-black storage room - “more like a dungeon,” Taylor said with a laugh - the duo found  musty, unmarked boxes.
musty.word_definition: covered with or smelling of mold

cache.word_example: A biography of the poet that draws on a newly discovered  cache of letters.

patina.word_example: “The  patina was very old and it looked dark and dingy in comparison to what it should look like,” he said.
patina.word_definition: a fine coating of oxide on the surface of a metal

hoard.word_example: Lifting the lid, she gapes at the  hoard of gold coins.
hoard.word_definition: save up as for future use

authentic.word_example: Inside, there are displays of  authentic swords and suits of armor, along with a reconstructed guillotine that was last used in 1861.

memento.word_example: She gestured toward a lone  memento that would remain in his bedroom, a life-size needlepoint portrait of her only child, woven in shimmering gold thread.

Eclipse Vocabulary.list_brief_description: On Monday, August 21, 2017 there will be a total eclipse of the sun. The moon will appear to completely block the sun for a few minutes, and we will experience ...

occult.word_example: “As the Moon begins to  occult the Sun more and more, you will need to lengthen the exposure a little bit,” Starr says.
occult.word_definition: become concealed or hidden from view

celestial.word_example: Across the country, both amateur and professional scientists are gearing up for what is sure to be the  celestial spectacle of the decade.
celestial.word_definition: relating to or inhabiting a divine heaven

penumbra.word_example: The moon will pass into Earth’s  penumbra, or outer shadow.
penumbra.word_definition: a fringe region of partial shadow around an umbra

eclipse.word_example: As millions of people move into position for Monday’s solar  eclipse, some airlines are encouraging travelers to get a little closer to the action.
eclipse.word_definition: the phenomenon when one celestial body obscures another

orbit.word_example: The moon moves in its own  orbit from west to east, and this is what causes the shadow to move from west to east.
orbit.word_definition: the path of a celestial body in its revolution about another

obscure.word_example: Astronomers routinely study the sun’s wispy atmosphere using coronagraphs, telescope attachments that  obscure the surface glare of the sun.

coincide.word_example: The eclipse  coincides with the Crow Tribe’s annual parade dance, marking the Montana tribe’s new year.

Eclipse Vocabulary.list_detailed_description: On Monday, August 21, 2017 there will be a total eclipse of the sun. The moon will appear to completely block the sun for a few minutes, and we will experience darkness in the middle of the day. When you can see this happening depends on where you are in the country. The United States hasn't had an eclipse of this kind since 1979. Below are some vocabulary words related to this extraordinary celestial event.

eldritch.word_definition: suggesting the operation of supernatural influences

monster.word_definition: an imaginary creature usually having human and animal parts

haunt.word_definition: follow stealthily or pursue like a ghost

pall.word_definition: burial garment in which a corpse is wrapped

strange.word_definition: unusual or out of the ordinary

horrendous.word_definition: causing fear or dread or terror

terror.word_definition: an overwhelming feeling of fear and anxiety

unearthly.word_definition: suggesting the operation of supernatural influences

bizarre.word_definition: conspicuously or grossly unconventional or unusual

wraith.word_definition: a mental representation of some haunting experience

May the 4th Be With You: Star Words.list_brief_description: Rejoice, Star Wars fans! May the 4th is National Star Wars Day! The epic film series launched plenty of words—like Jedi and Wookiee—but it also made use of ...

phantom.word_example: Well, almost the first: Lucas, lest we forget, introduced the servile TC-14 for an early scene in The  Phantom Menace.

alliance.word_description: The good guys in Star Wars are part of the Rebel Alliance. An alliance brings together different people and factions, like the Allied Powers in World War II. An ally is a friend you can count on.  Alliance gained popularity thanks to reality TV shows where characters make alliances: secret pacts designed to ensure their survival and crush other contestants. When you’re in an alliance, you have friends—and usually enemies too. That’s why you needed the friends in the first place.
alliance.word_example: Then again, there appear to be more bug-eyed lobster men than women among the highest ranks of the Rebel  Alliance.

force.word_description: As the old joke goes, the force in Star Wars is like duct tape: it has a light side, a dark side, and it holds the universe together. In our universe, the  force is a broad term for various types of strength and power. An anvil falling from a great height has a lot of force. Employees are called the workforce, and if you have a lot of them, you can get more done. When countries go to war, they’ve decided to use force instead of diplomacy. Forces get stuff done.
force.word_example: “The  force is strong with this one.” – Darth Vader

destiny.word_description: In the original trilogy, Darth Vader tried to convince his son Luke that the farm boy’s destiny was to rule the galaxy with pop. Someone’s  destiny is their fate. If something is destined to happen, then it has to happen.
destiny.word_example: He admired Luke Skywalker for finding within himself “the resources of character to meet his  destiny.”
destiny.word_definition: a course of events that will inevitably happen in the future

clone.word_description: Do you love yourself? If you said yes, then you should become a genetic engineer and make yourself a clone. A  clone is a genetic copy of someone: clones look exactly the same, much like identical twins. The stormtroopers in the first three Star Wars movies (and those execrable prequels) were clones. In fact, they were a clone army. Hey, if you can’t recruit an army of jackbooted thugs, why not grow them in a petri dish?
clone.word_example: She earned this position by becoming one of the first Galactic senators to publicly object to Emperor Palpatine’s rise to power during the  Clone Wars.
clone.word_definition: a person who is almost identical to another

mission.word_example: “I’m a member of the Imperial Senate on a diplomatic  mission to Alderaan.” – Princess Leia
mission.word_definition: an operation that is assigned by a higher headquarters

imperial.word_description: Another Star Wars word refer to empires:  imperial. In addition to referring to an actual empire, things and people described as imperial are majestic, commanding, or high-and-mighty.
imperial.word_example: Like Darth Vader preparing to unleash a Force choke on a garrulous  Imperial officer, we view such frivolities with icy scorn.
imperial.word_definition: relating to or associated with an empire

menace.word_example: On Global News, a Star Wars fan snarkily joked that “someone probably showed him Phantom  Menace.”
menace.word_definition: something that is a source of danger

millennium.word_example: There are a lot of callbacks to the cantina scene and the  Millennium Falcon being a piece of junk.

deceive.word_example: “Your eyes can  deceive you. Don’t trust them.” – Obi-Wan Kenobi
deceive.word_definition: cause someone to believe an untruth

disturbing.word_example: “I find your lack of faith  disturbing.” – Darth Vader
disturbing.word_definition: causing distress or worry or anxiety

empire.word_description: The bad guys in Star Wars are the empire—the galactic empire. This isn’t a sloppy word choice, since the leader of the empire is an emperor—excuse me, THE Emperor. With his repressive regime and freaky lightning shooting out of his fingertips, the Emperor is not a contender for the Star Wars equivalent of the Nobel Peace Prize.  Empire was originally a borrowing from French and refers a realm or territory with an absolute ruler: an empire is the opposite of a democracy.
empire.word_example: The  empire in “Star Wars” gets a bad rap.
empire.word_definition: the domain ruled by an emperor or empress

rebellion.word_example: Nearly four decades later, she was still playing Leia, only now as a general of the  rebellion in “Star Wars: The Force Awakens.”

galaxy.word_description: How many people have learned this word from the famous opening crawl of Star Wars? “A long time ago, in a galaxy far, far away…”  Galaxy is part of a sequence of increasingly larger cosmic stuff we’re part of: planet, solar system, galaxy, universe. A galaxy contains a whole bunch of solar systems, each of which has a sun and some planets.
galaxy.word_example: Is he a Jedi teleported from the distant past and  galaxies far far away?

apprentice.word_definition: someone who works for an expert to learn a trade

May the 4th Be With You: Star Words.list_detailed_description: Rejoice, Star Wars fans! May the 4th is

A Web of Lies.list_brief_description: Let's face it, we all (or at least most of us) lie. Whether you just want to spare someone's feelings or want to get away with something you really shouldn't be...

falsehood.word_example: The First Amendment protects the right of free speech, but defamation laws protect the innocent against malicious  falsehoods.

fraud.word_example: I was afraid he would turn on me with disgust and accuse me of my  fraud, but he still seemed flattered.
fraud.word_definition: deliberate trickery intended to gain an advantage

deception.word_example: The most fascinating element of the story is watching a daring act of  deception coalesce into the solid-seeming shape of history.

duplicity.word_description: Duplicity comes from a Latin root that means “double” and this is another very popular characterization of the liar — they are presenting two very different selves to the world, and it becomes immediately unclear which of the two, if any, can be trusted.
duplicity.word_example: The mission of a news organization is to record accurately the course of events, including patterns of deception and  duplicity.

fabrication.word_example: About a third of allegations of plagiarism,  fabrication, piracy and misconduct were upheld.
fabrication.word_definition: a deliberately false or improbable account

perfidy.word_example: Nicknamed "yahoo-yahoo" after the international web portal and search engine, this  perfidy has become a way of life for the young con-artists.

perjury.word_example: Court documents alleged that Hatfield falsely reported the reasons for Lewis’ retirement, leading to a felony  perjury charge against him.
perjury.word_definition: criminal offense of making false statements under oath

obfuscate.word_example: Briefings are often—as the Ziegler example underscores—a means of  obfuscating the truth.

dissemble.word_description: Dissemble sounds like taking something apart, as if someone has said “disassemble” very fast. But rather than taking something apart, you can think of dissemble as constructing something, like a costume or a mask to hide one’s true self. The dissembler builds a disguise, either of fabric or words to conceal that which they don’t want exposed.
dissemble.word_example: She believes nothing and lies and  dissembles casually.
dissemble.word_definition: make believe with the intent to deceive

subterfuge.word_description: This word emphasizes the skill of the liar. To practice subterfuge one must be slick and stealthy, easily avoiding capture by the people you just “put one over on” who are now chasing you. If a student cheats on a test by writing the answers on their hand, it's not subterfuge. A conspiracy to supply an entire class with all the answers to all the tests for the semester is closer to subterfuge.
subterfuge.word_example: Why do you believe that  subterfuge and dishonesty are appropriate tactics to use on your wife?
subterfuge.word_definition: something intended to misrepresent the nature of an activity

deceit.word_description: Deceit comes from Latin  decipere, which means “to ensnare, take in, beguile, cheat.” Every lie is, in one way or another, an attempt to ensnare someone in a story, to beguile them into believing you. To practice deceit is to mislead, and it gets to the core of what lying is all about.
deceit.word_example: He displays “extreme narcissism,” the author argues, and he lies compulsively, with  deceit as “an ingrained way of life.”

mendacity.word_description: We all lie when cornered, but that doesn’t mean we exhibit mendacity or are mendacious. Mendacity is a character trait, something that defines you, which suggests that lying is an essential part of who you are. On both sides of the political aisle, it has become commonplace to suggest that someone you don’t like has a “casual relationship with the truth.” Someone who doesn’t take the truth seriously is showing mendacity.
mendacity.word_example: Truth tellers are especially important and potentially vulnerable in an administration afflicted with serial  mendacity.

prevaricate.word_description: Prevaricate is a polite way to say that you have purposefully confused a situation by telling half-truths. The word comes from Latin praevaricatus, which literally means “to walk crookedly” a good metaphor for following the path of the habitual liar if there ever was one. Prevarication is intimately tied up with concept of evasion, when you don’t want to be nailed down to the facts or held to account.
prevaricate.word_example: People are  prevaricating; distracting, making listeners believe things that aren’t always factually true.

A Web of Lies.list_detailed_description: Let's face it, we all (or at least most of us) lie. Whether you just want to spare someone's feelings or want to get away with something you really shouldn't be doing, people bend the truth on occasion. It's no surprise, then, that there are so many words that describe the telling of untruths. Whether the motivation is malicious or kindhearted, there is a nuanced way to describe it. Here are fifteen words to describe liars and the webs they spin.

St. Patrick's Day Vocabulary: Words From.list_brief_description: With St. Patrick's Day — and celebrations of all things Irish — coming up on March 17th, learn 10 words derived from the Irish language. For more words from...

hooligan.word_description: Probably from a form of the Irish surname "Houlihan."
hooligan.word_example: Mixing with the crowd, they saw masked snipers and chain-wielding  hooligans, talked to participants and witnessed a fire that killed more than 40 pro-Russian demonstrators.

boycott.word_description: From an English name, one Captain Charles C. Boycott, who refused to lower rents on Irish tenant farmers and was opposed by the Irish Land League in the late 19th Century.
boycott.word_example: A Roman Catholic bishop in the Philippines this week urged the faithful to  boycott Madonna's shows over her "suggestive" performance and "vulgar" clothes.
boycott.word_definition: refusal to have commercial dealings with some organization

smithereens.word_example: Scientists who tried managing energies of the necessary magnitude often ended up with equipment blown to  smithereens and laboratories littered with glass shards.
smithereens.word_definition: a collection of small fragments considered as a whole

keen.word_example: His  keening caterwaul sounds as if he had flicked the ejector switch but forgotten to undo his seat belt.

slew.word_example: A  slew of food delivery apps and startups have sprung up across the French capital in recent months, and they're impossible to miss.
slew.word_definition: a large number or amount or extent

bog.word_example: The weather has turned against us, and the plains, covered with snow two days ago, have turned to a swampy, shoe-sucking mud  bog.
bog.word_definition: wet spongy ground of decomposing vegetation

St. Patrick's Day Vocabulary: Words From.list_detailed_description: With St. Patrick's Day — and celebrations of all things Irish — coming up on March 17th, learn 10 words derived from the Irish language. For more words from the Emerald Isle, read the article:

Spider-Man's Word Web.list_brief_description: Even if a new Spider-Man movie keeps coming more often than Leap Year, the lingo of Spider-Man is eternal and unique. Enjoy these words inspired by the "web-hea...

radioactive.word_description: Spider-Man’s origin involved getting bit by a radioactive spider: in other words, a spider that had become  irradiated with  radiation. Radiation is a specific sort of intense energy consisting of electromagnetic particles. If only radiation worked like it does in Marvel Comics, where cosmic radiation created the Fantastic Four, gamma rays created the Hulk, and radiation in general created mutants like the X-Men. In real life, too much radiation is anything but super.
radioactive.word_example: Peter Parker was a simple high school geek before a bite from a  radioactive spider transformed him into Spider-Man.
radioactive.word_definition: exhibiting or caused by emissions in nuclear decay

adolescent.word_description: Does the word  teen sound too casual or cutesy to you? Then there's always  adolescent, which means the same. You can also refer to the teen years as adolescence. Since teens are sometimes stereotyped as being moody and self-centered, this word is also used as an insult for older people. An adult who's rude, sulky, or otherwise immature can be called adolescent. Before his Uncle Ben died, Peter was an adolescent literally and figuratively. He had a lot of growing up to do.
adolescent.word_example: Anna May Dutton started skateboarding to channel her  adolescent energy.
adolescent.word_definition: a juvenile between the onset of puberty and maturity

reptilian.word_description: Many of Spider-Man's enemies have pseudo-scientific origins—such as Dr. Curtis Connors, the Lizard. Lizards are reptiles that are closely related to snakes, consisting of over 4000 species that are mostly long, green, and scaly. Many can regenerate limbs, which is what interested Connors. He was trying to regrow his own missing arm but ended up turning into a freaky lizard man instead, with many reptilian qualities. This is why comic-book science is not recommended by doctors.
reptilian.word_example: At least a dozen mortal guards stood on the balcony, plus two monsters— reptilian women with doublesnake trunks instead of legs.
reptilian.word_definition: of or relating to cold-blooded vertebrates with scaly skin

orphan.word_description: Peter Parker, when first introduced in the comics and movies, lives with his Aunt May and Uncle Ben. That's because his parents died: Peter was adopted by his aunt and uncle. When someone doesn't have any parents, they're an orphan. For some reason, being an orphan is strongly correlated with being a superhero. Batman's parents were murdered. Superman's parents died on Krypton. Captain America's parents died young. Even James Bond is an orphan. No wonder villainous fiends are so anti-orphanage.
orphan.word_example: Then the wife died, the husband was sent to a nursing home and Louie became an  orphan.
orphan.word_definition: a child who has lost both parents

fluid.word_description: Peter Parker is a whiz at science, which is why he was interested in the particle accelerator that irradiated that pesky spider. This scientific interest also allowed Peter to invent his own web fluid. This web fluid shoots out in liquid form, then hardens in exactly the way he wants it to, whether to create a line for swinging or a giant net. Hey, if you're looking for realism, Spider-Man stories aren't the place.
fluid.word_example: “It’s like slime,” she said, referring to another type of non-Newtonian  fluid.
fluid.word_definition: continuous amorphous matter that tends to flow

responsibility.word_description: Spider-Man’s motto is: “With great power comes great responsibility.” Peter learns this lesson the hard way during his famous origin, when he is so consumed with a chance to make money as a wrestler that he fails to stop a bad guy who had just committed a robbery. That bad guy—who Peter could have easily grabbed or tripped—ends up murdering Peter’s Uncle Ben. That’s when Peter decides he might need to do more with his powers than use them for his own gain.
responsibility.word_definition: the social force that binds you to a course of action

remorse.word_description: Because Spider-Man feels at fault for the death of his Uncle Ben, he is consumed by remorse—an emotion made up of regret and sadness. When you feel remorseful, you blame yourself for something. Despite his wisecracks, remorsefulness is the defining trait of Spider-Man, who always feels like he has to make up for the past. Subsequent events in the comics—such as the death of his girlfriend Gwen Stacy—add to his guilt. It's not easy being Spidey.
remorse.word_example: Filled with  remorse, he sat on the ground and cried.
remorse.word_definition: a feeling of deep regret, usually for some misdeed

nerd.word_description: This word has a positive and negative meaning: a nerd can be an insult for someone considered uncool or a compliment for someone consumed by something, like a computer nerd or a comic book nerd.
nerd.word_example: May 6 is the great, geek holiday Free Comic Book Day, an annual celebration of reading, art and  nerd fellowship.
nerd.word_definition: an intelligent but single-minded expert in a technical field

Spider-Man's Word Web.list_detailed_description: Even if a new Spider-Man movie keeps coming more often than Leap Year, the lingo of Spider-Man is eternal and unique. Enjoy these words inspired by the "web-headed menace."

Wonder Woman's Superpower Words.list_brief_description: As a mere mortal you may lack Wonder Woman's heroic powers, but you can still attain a super vocabulary by learning these words. For the full article, check out...

origin.word_example: The film taps the teen comedy genre in the retelling of Spider-Man's  origin story as his alter-ego Peter Parker navigates the perils of high school.

warrior.word_description: This word for a person who wages war has been mostly associated with men, but Wonder Woman isn't the type of princess who needs to be rescued: she's the one doing the rescuing and brawling. Wonder Woman has a lot in common with Princess Leia, another royal type who wasn't afraid to mix it up.
warrior.word_example: From a tender age, Diana, living on the achingly idyllic island of Themyscira, dreams of being a  warrior.
warrior.word_definition: someone engaged in or experienced in warfare

psychologist.word_description: Psychologists are experts in the field of psychology, and they study human behavior. This word probably seems out of place in a list about Wonder Woman, but it is crucial to her history: Wonder Woman was co-created by psychologist and inventor William Moulton Marston who, besides writing comic books, helped develop a device that's remarkably similar to the lasso of truth: he contributed to the invention of the polygraph, commonly known as the lie detector.
psychologist.word_example: She still attends as many as five appointments a week with physical therapists, doctors and a  psychologist.
psychologist.word_definition: a specialist in the science of mental life

justice.word_description: Most heroes fight for justice in some way, but this word is extra-applicable to Wonder Woman, who has been a member of the Justice Society of America (the very first super-team, founded in 1941) and the Justice League of America (an updated version founded in 1960). Unfortunately, Wonder Woman was originally the secretary for the Justice Society, so let's just say American society has evolved a little bit since then.
justice.word_example: Greater than the sum of their awe-inspiring parts, the  Justice League handles threats too massive for any single hero. Made up of the World’s Greatest Super Heroes, their membership inflates and contracts around each new threat, but the core line-up is known as the Big Seven. DC Comics
justice.word_definition: the quality of being just or fair

indestructible.word_description: Something indestructible can't be smashed, broken, crushed, or otherwise annihilated: Wonder Woman's Lasso of Truth is indestructible.
indestructible.word_example: Batman has amazing fighting skills and weapons, but Superman is basically  indestructible and could just throw him out to Saturn if he wanted to.

clay.word_description: This is the soft stuff sculptors mold into statues. In one version of Wonder Woman's origin, she was made out of clay by the gods.
clay.word_example: They never learned how to model in  clay, carve marble or weld metal.

villain.word_example: His green hair matches that of the comic book and movie  villain.

isolated.word_example: That creation was Diana Prince, who, upon landing in America from her  isolated Paradise Island, donned the identity of Wonder Woman.
isolated.word_definition: remote and separate physically or socially

sensation.word_description: A sensation can be a feeling or something exceptional. Many of Wonder Woman’s early adventures were published in  Sensation Comics.
sensation.word_example: Summer 1942: Solo stardom: Wonder Woman proves so popular that she gets her own comic book with  Sensation Comics.
sensation.word_definition: a general feeling of excitement and heightened interest

amazon.word_example: Gal Gadot plays the  Amazon princess-turned-superhero, introduced last year in “Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice.”. Los Angeles Times (May 30, 2017)
amazon.word_definition: a large, strong, and aggressive woman

paradise.word_description: This word is synonymous with heaven: in paradise, there's no more pain, and we can all eat chocolate and pizza all day without ever gaining a pound. Nothing's better than paradise.
paradise.word_example: Wonder Woman The Amazonian princess gets her own movie and leaves her island  paradise to fight a war to end all wars.
paradise.word_definition: any place of complete bliss and delight and peace

invisible.word_example: “It has this capacity to go from being visible to  invisible, so their pelts can be used to make invisibility cloaks,” Mr. Redmayne said.
invisible.word_definition: impossible or nearly impossible to see

mythology.word_description: Mythology refers to the stories of a group of people, especially stories that explain how the world came to be and what the gods (there are usually a bunch of them) are up to. Wonder Woman's history involves a lot of interaction with mythology: in one version of her origin, she's the daughter of Hippolyta and Zeus. Also, mythology can be used more loosely these days. The back story of a TV show is often called its mythology, and superhero stories are a type of modern mythology too.
mythology.word_example: In about a decade, the ridiculously prolific and innovative Kirby co-created the Marvel Universe, then moved to DC to create another  mythology.
mythology.word_definition: the body of stories associated with a culture or institution

heroine.word_description: This word for a female hero is a little out of fashion, depending on who you ask. Over time, people have tended to throw gendered words in the lexical dumpster, replacing  stewardess with  flight attendant and  actress with  actor. But sometimes people want to emphasize the femaleness of a hero, so  heroine still has a place in English.
heroine.word_example: Yet, like the  heroine at its center, “Wonder Woman” the movie rises with powerful grace above the noise.
heroine.word_definition: the main good female character in a work of fiction

lasso.word_description: The lasso is mostly associated with cowboys: it's a rope with a loop tied at the end, and a skilled roper can swing the thing so accurately that it lands just right on a bull, or some other critter, to bring it down. Wonder Woman's home of Paradise Island is pretty far from the Wild West, but her main weapon is a lasso—the Lasso of Truth, which has sometimes been called the Magic Lasso and Golden Lasso. When she wraps it around someone, they're forced to tell the truth.
lasso.word_example: But her weapon of choice is the  lasso of truth.
lasso.word_definition: a long noosed rope used to catch animals

Wonder Woman's Superpower Words.list_detailed_description: As a mere mortal you may lack Wonder Woman's heroic powers, but you can still attain a super vocabulary by learning these words. For the full article, check out:

Words Every Pirate Should Know.list_brief_description: International Talk Like A Pirate Day is celebrated on September 19. In the swashbuckling spirit, this list covers words every self-respecting pirate should know...

scurvy.word_description: This is a disease many pirates would contract because there was a lack of fresh fruit or other sources of Vitamin C.
scurvy.word_example: Scurvy, an 18th century disease caused by a lack of vitamin C, appears to have made a surprise comeback in Australia.
scurvy.word_definition: a condition caused by deficiency of ascorbic acid

booty.word_example: He made me think of a pirate captain disposing of the  booty.

careen.word_description: This verb originally applied to ships and is from a French word which literally translates as "to expose a ship's
careen.word_example: Then a car roared past him,  careening all over the road, in the opposite direction.

prow.word_description: The word for the front part of a ship,
prow.word_example: Instead of a knife she used a blade that curved like the  prow of a Viking ship, sailing to battle in distant seas.
prow.word_definition: the front part of a vessel

pillage.word_example: “Beaten, bleeding, terrified, the men lay huddled together in the hold, while the pirates proceeded in their work of  pillage and brutality.

fathom.word_example: The film borrowed heavily from a recent American picture, “The Beast From 20,000  Fathoms,” but put a distinctly Japanese spin on the allegory.
fathom.word_definition: a linear unit of measurement for water depth

maroon.word_example: Estimates of losses were not available, with rescuers yet to reach villages  marooned by the worst floods in recent years.
maroon.word_definition: leave stranded or isolated with little hope of rescue

keel.word_description: The keel is the lowest plank of wood on a boat. It is the foundational piece, and the ship depends on it for strength and stability. The phrase "keep an even keel" comes from maintaining a level, horizontal position on a ship, and has been metaphorically extended to mean keeping a calm demeanor and not going from one extreme emotion to another.
keel.word_example: But the  keel remained intact, and the boat eventually righted itself, though it was flooded.
keel.word_definition: one of the main longitudinal beams of the hull of a vessel

hoist.word_example: Drenched pirates shouted and  hoisted and scrambled, but there was nothing to be done.
hoist.word_definition: raise or haul up with or as if with mechanical help

unfurl.word_example: The queen herself was seen summoning the winds,  Unfurling her sails and frantically paying out the slackened ropes.
unfurl.word_definition: to unroll, unfold, or spread out

stern.word_description: The stern is where the steering gear of the ship is located, and the word derives from Old Norse
stern.word_example: That  stern of a Turkish gulet where 10 of us slept on cushions under the stars.
stern.word_definition: the rear part of a ship

buccaneer.word_example: Buccaneers and pirate-wannabes of all ages abound, since pirate attire is encouraged and usually available from event vendors.
buccaneer.word_definition: someone who robs at sea or plunders the land from the sea

ballast.word_example: The  ballast water that stabilizes marine vessels is the greatest source of harmful bacteria and invasive species in aquatic ecosystems.
ballast.word_definition: any heavy material used to stabilize a ship or airship

Cat Vocabulary: A Feline Lexicon.list_brief_description: Whether you're a cat-person or have a case of feline phobia, here are 13 words to describe these lithe, stealthy creatures.

pounce.word_example: As the lion  pounced, it knocked over a platform that fell and blocked the gate to the cage.
pounce.word_definition: move down on as if in an attack

carnivore.word_example: The danger of overidentifying with animals, particularly  carnivores, is that it leads people to expect human behavior of them.
carnivore.word_definition: any animal that feeds on flesh

lissome.word_example: The  lissome cheetah, meanwhile, is bullied and often killed by bigger carnivores such as lions.

agile.word_example: Faster and more  agile than their bulk would indicate, they can run about 35 miles an hour.

feline.word_example: That’s because the early-morning visitor was no domestic  feline munching on some unlucky rodent.

predator.word_example: It’s designed to warn birds that there’s a  predator nearby.
predator.word_definition: any animal that lives by preying on other animals

stealthy.word_definition: marked by quiet and caution and secrecy

lithe.word_example: Hylla was in her twenties,  lithe and lean as a tiger.

stalk.word_example: Their paws are perfectly moistened to keep their movement quiet, helping them  stalk their prey.
stalk.word_definition: a hunt for game carried on by following it stealthily

aloof.word_example: Cats, depending on your point of view, are cute or  aloof, predatory or lazy.

supple.word_example: It’s also the most formally inventive: part play, part dance, with  supple, catlike movement illustrating recorded dialogue by the playwright Jonathon Young.

domesticated.word_example: In most cases, adoption is out of the question for feral cats because they are just too wild to be  domesticated.

Cat Vocabulary: A Feline Lexicon.list_detailed_description: Whether you're a cat-person or have a case of feline phobia, here are 13 words to describe these lithe, stealthy creatures.

Automobiles.list_brief_description: Henry Ford's Model-T was first produced in October 1908. It was the cheapest car ever built, and it helped usher in a new age of transportation. Whether you're ...

acceleration.word_example: It’s a car model that I really enjoy driving, with excellent handling and  acceleration.
acceleration.word_definition: (physics) a rate of increase of velocity

manufacture.word_example: While lighter plastic car parts might help cut vehicle emissions and increase the range of electric cars, doesn't their  manufacture bring other environmental risks?
manufacture.word_definition: organized action of making of goods and services for sale

cylinder.word_example: The engine in the base Cooper — which starts at $20,745 — is also notable because it has just three  cylinders.
cylinder.word_definition: a chamber within which a piston moves

lemon.word_example: It was impossible to tell whether it was Mom’s driving or whether we had bought a  lemon.
lemon.word_definition: an object, especially a car, that is defective or deficient

velocity.word_example: It can also reach a top speed of 155 mph, up from the Model S’s peak  velocity of 130 mph.

accelerator.word_example: He likes the instant torque, the zero hesitation when he steps on the  accelerator.
accelerator.word_definition: a pedal that controls the throttle valve

transmission.word_example: Built for quickness and nothing else, semi-automatic  transmissions were far too jerky and unrefined for the road in the early 1990s.
transmission.word_definition: the gears that transfer power from an automobile engine

combustible.word_example: For enthusiasts, there was much ogling at under-the-hood advancements of the  combustible engine.

torque.word_example: There is an unwritten mandate that every time a new car model arrives, it has to have more horsepower and  torque than its predecessor.

jalopy.word_example: They pass the carcasses of old  jalopies, front ends fallen through the ice, doors riddled with bullet holes.
jalopy.word_definition: a car that is old and unreliable

axle.word_example: The gas tank was mounted behind the rear  axle, leaving it vulnerable in a crash.
axle.word_definition: a shaft on which a wheel rotates

vehicle.word_example: Electric  vehicles use rechargeable batteries containing cobalt, a byproduct of copper and nickel output, which boosts energy density and extends battery life.
vehicle.word_definition: a conveyance that transports people or objects

suspension.word_example: Because Jeeps have a looser  suspension than most cars, their frames absorb every bump in the road.
suspension.word_definition: a mechanical system of springs or shock absorbers

throttle.word_example: I hit the  throttle — and then realize I’m out of fuel.
throttle.word_definition: a valve that regulates the supply of fuel to the engine

prototype.word_example: He added, “Our research vehicle  prototype we think is the most perceptive car in the world.”

modernize.word_example: Uber is striving to  modernize an entrenched industry and bring it, however reluctantly, into the digital age.
modernize.word_definition: make repairs, renovations, revisions or adjustments to

carburetor.word_example: The fuel injection delivers an even flow of gas to the engine, something that  carburetors couldn’t always do.
carburetor.word_definition: the part of a combustion engine that mixes air with gasoline

Automobiles.list_detailed_description: Henry Ford's Model-T was first produced in October 1908. It was the cheapest car ever built, and it helped usher in a new age of transportation. Whether you're an automotive enthusiast or a total novice, check out these words connected to cars.

Father's Day Words.list_brief_description: There is so much more to dads than a bunch of words, but these terms at least cover the tip of the word-berg that describes both the clichés and the changing c...

patriarchal.word_description: Patriarchal is related to  paternal, and it refers to all sorts of leaders—as long as they're male. A male-dominated society is patriarchal: the opposite, a female-dominated society, is matriarchal. The person in charge of a patriarchy is the patriarch, and you can also refer to a dad as the patriarch of a family, usually as a joke. We all know moms really run the world, right?
patriarchal.word_example: A contemporary described Pike as “a man of gigantic frame and his long waving white hair and silky beard gave him a decidedly  patriarchal appearance.”
patriarchal.word_definition: of a social organization with the male as the head

discipline.word_description: In families, probably because men are perceived (right or wrong) as being scarier than women, dads are often stuck with the job of "laying down the law" if one of the kids crashed the car, flunked a class, or committed some other atrocity. A classic, if clichéd, threat of moms, when dealing with troublesome kids, is "Wait till your father comes home!" At home or school, kids have a choice: be disciplined or get disciplined.
discipline.word_example: My father had a stern manner and did not spare the rod when  disciplining his children.
discipline.word_definition: a system of rules of conduct or method of practice

devoted.word_example: He was a  devoted dad who was always there for his children, whether that meant teaching them to throw a baseball, change a flat tire, or help with their homework.

sportsmanship.word_description: While it's a stereotypical idea that all fathers are into sports, many fathers do combine sports and parenting by teaching the quality of sportsmanship. If you have sportsmanship, you respect the rules, play fair, and respect your opponent. In other words, you're a good sport.
sportsmanship.word_example: It was the tool by which Palmer’s father instilled in his son lasting lessons about  sportsmanship and self-respect.
sportsmanship.word_definition: fairness and courtesy in following the rules of a game

paternal.word_description: This word, with French and Latin roots, covers everything father-ish: if there were a whole school of father-related topics, it would probably be called the Academy of Paternal Studies. This word can also be used loosely for anyone acting like a dad, in a positive or negative way. If you patted me on the head and gave me some old-timey advice, that would be a wee bit paternal of you.
paternal.word_example: "She lacked a  paternal figure, from birth. She never met her father. This affected her entire life."

foster.word_description: Foster dads are fathers, too. Fostering positive qualities, such as sportsmanship and discipline, is a classic responsibility of fatherhood.
foster.word_example: Martha’s maternal instincts bubble up as she coaxes Philip to become a  foster dad.
foster.word_definition: providing nurture though not related by blood or legal ties

provider.word_description: Yet another traditional role of fathers is providing. Fathers have been expected to bring home the bacon, often literally, but also figuratively in the sense of making enough money to provide food, clothes, shelter, and other necessities of life such as smartphones and fidget spinners. These days, such stereotypical notions aren’t dead, but they aren’t quite as thriving as before: if a family has two parents, it’s a good bet both are providing.
provider.word_example: I rode, feeling proud of myself as a hunter and a  provider for the family.
provider.word_definition: someone who supplies the means for subsistence

nurture.word_description: Anyone who takes good care of their kids knows how to nurture, including penguin dads. If you've ever seen  March of the Penguins, you know penguin fathers protect their eggs for months in freezing conditions, far from warmth or recliners.
nurture.word_example: The most prominent black man in the world is a  nurturing father and dutiful, faithful husband, who is intelligent, measured and even-tempered.

supportive.word_example: My dad was a teacher; he was pliable and  supportive and useless.

recliner.word_description: Here's another stereotype with a load of truth: a good place to find many dads is in the recliner, a type of soft living room chair that extends back, making it more comfortable to watch the ballgame, read the paper, or take a nap. A recliner  reclines. This term has been around since the late 1800s.
recliner.word_example: “At home, he spends most of his time in a  recliner just watching TV.”
recliner.word_definition: an armchair whose back can be lowered

Father's Day Words.list_detailed_description: There is so much more to dads than a bunch of words, but these terms at least cover the tip of the word-berg that describes both the clichés and the changing culture of fatherhood.

Basketball Words for March Madness.list_brief_description: March Madness basketball and brackets are pure mania, but the related words are pretty chill, right? Think again. Do YOU know all five meanings of foul? Test yo...

court.word_description: Many sports—such as baseball, football, and soccer—are played on a field. Not basketball, which takes place on a court. This is one of many meanings of  court, including a place where you’d find a judge or king and any closed-in area (such as a courtyard). The other major sport that takes place on a court is tennis, though if you try to play basketball on a tennis court, you might need to retake Sports 101.
court.word_example: As Highland stormed up and down the basketball  court Thursday, there was plenty of physical play under the basket.
court.word_definition: a specially marked area within which a game is played

center.word_description: The center is located at the middle of anything, from a circle to a city. That concept is stretched just a little in basketball:  center is the name of one of the three positions, along with forward and guard. Fittingly, there’s only one center, while there are two guards (point and shooting) and two forwards (power and small). The center is usually the biggest player on the court.
center.word_example: The deal clears more cap space for the Lightning, who earlier in the week traded goaltender Ben Bishop and  center Brian Boyle.
center.word_definition: position of a basketball player who participates in the jump

zone.word_description: In basketball, the main use of  zone is in  zone defense, which is the opposite of  man-to-man defense. In a zone defense, the defenders don’t have specific assignments: they cover areas of the court. This is often a losing strategy, since not having a specific player to follow can lead to chaos and anarchy, which aren’t as fun as they sound. When a player is lighting up the scoreboard—scoring points—you can also say they’re  in the zone.
zone.word_example: No. 12 West Virginia has undone opponents in the past three games not with a relentless press but with a throwback  zone defense.

rebound.word_description: You can rebound from a failed relationship by starting a new one, and you can rebound from losing your job by spiffing up your resume and replacing that tie with the mustard stains. But in basketball, a rebound is much more literal: it’s any time the ball bounces off the backboard or rim, doesn’t go through the hoop, and a player grabs it.
rebound.word_example: Her layup attempt bounced around the top the iron and rolled off with Joyner grabbing the  rebound and getting fouled.
rebound.word_definition: securing possession of the basketball after a missed shot

assist.word_description: If you throw me the ball and I make a basket, I may get the glory of scoring 2 or 3 points, but you receive something besides a warm feeling inside: an assist. Assists are passes that directly set up scoring. Any player can make as assist, but usually the quarterback-like point guard gets the most assists.
assist.word_example: De’Sean Parsons added 14 points for Portland State with five rebounds and four  assists.
assist.word_definition: the act of enabling another player to make a good play

upset.word_description: People get upset for lots of reasons, from politics to parking, but in the NCAA Tournament an upset occurs when a lower-ranked team beats a higher-ranked team. Upsets are inevitable, and they’re a big part of what makes March Madness bonkers.
upset.word_example: He missed four games, and Northwestern lost three of them — although the one victory was an impressive  upset of Wisconsin on the road.

foul.word_description: This versatile word can be an adjective, noun, or verb. It can describe a stinky smell (“Yikes, what is the foul odor?”) that assaults your nostrils, and that gross meaning might help you member the basketball meaning: a violation of the rules. The referee blows the whistle when one player fouls the other, resulting in free throws for the victim.
foul.word_example: “The players decided the game, and it wasn’t just with free throws, and with  fouling,” he said.
foul.word_definition: an act that violates the rules of a sport

guard.word_example: Point  guard Lonzo Ball was selected national freshman of the year by USA Today and the Sporting News.
guard.word_definition: a position on a basketball team

forward.word_example: Update: This will be the final time Clippers  forward Paul Pierce, who’s retiring after 19 seasons in the NBA, will play against the Celtics.
forward.word_definition: a position on a basketball, soccer, or hockey team

dribble.word_example: Murphy provided the ignition, when he grabbed a long rebound and  dribbled into the lane for a powerful two-handed dunk and a 30-25 advantage.

Basketball Words for March Madness.list_detailed_description: March Madness basketball and brackets are pure mania, but the related words are pretty chill, right? Think again. Do YOU know all five meanings of

Change Your Mind.list_brief_description: A person is entitled to change their mind. Sometimes, however, this switch can be seen as a betrayal to the people you used to side with and have now left behin...

renounce.word_description: This word is another one about changing your mind that deals in high stakes decisions. It is inappropriate to say that you’ve renounced your formerly favorite breakfast cereal because they removed your most-loved marshmallow shape, unless you are the celebrity spokesperson for said cereal — then it is a big deal.  Renounce is a word that not only entails switching your viewpoint, but also explicitly rejecting a formerly held opinion.
renounce.word_example: A favored tactic is public humiliation – forcing those who wrote negative comments to appear on local television to  renounce their views and apologize.

repudiate.word_description: From the Latin meaning “to cast off by divorce,”  repudiate is a clear example of a word that is used when you have really changed your mind and seek to separate yourself from your previously held beliefs.  Repudiate focuses on the demonization of where you were and not the positive aspects of where you are now.
repudiate.word_example: The authorities of the Scottish Episcopal Church should immediately  repudiate this ill-advised invitation and exercise appropriate discipline for those involved.”
repudiate.word_definition: refuse to acknowledge, ratify, or recognize as valid

abjure.word_description: Abjure is a word that takes leaving a former belief behind one step further — it means to swear an oath that you reject the previously held position.  Abjure seeks to stop flip-flopping right after the person has flipped to the “right” position. The extra pressure, or guilt, of an oath will perhaps prevent going back to your past position and make you indebted to your new-found outlook.
abjure.word_example: Scientists in the West generally  abjure this sort of research on the grounds that it amounts to genetic engineering of humans.
abjure.word_definition: formally reject or disavow a formerly held belief

disavow.word_description: To disavow is to break a promise or belief. In this case, disavowal also includes refusing to stand behind something previously supported by you or your organization. Often in times of crisis or scandal, people who have up until now been boosters for the accused will disavow them when the evidence against their former friend becomes too great or the scandal simply reaches epic proportions.
disavow.word_example: Professors in the sociology department  disavowed Edmonds’s remarks, saying, “We consider Professor Edmonds’s views to be unfounded, ill-advised and clearly insensitive.”

disclaim.word_example: When the photo surfaced in the last week of the campaign, Butler  disclaimed any knowledge of how it had come to be.

quash.word_example: Heavy gunfire erupted on Monday in Ivory Coast’s two largest cities as the military tried to  quash a four-day army mutiny over bonus payments.

renege.word_description: Renege means to go back on a promise or obligation. When used in this context, it fits well into the concept of “your word is your bond”- saying something, even without an explicit promise, compels you to act in ways that fit with how you said you would behave.
renege.word_example: He not only lies openly, but he  reneges on his promises daily.
renege.word_definition: fail to fulfill a promise or obligation

retract.word_example: But critics suspect that Hekma­tyar is unlikely to change his stripes, disarm his men or  retract his harsh criticisms.

abrogate.word_description: To abrogate something it is not enough to just speak out against it or separate yourself from it in a public manner. In order to abrogate one must formally revoke a previously filed document or opinion. A more common synonym for abrogate is “repeal”, as when a new administration seeks to repeal, or cancel, measures taken by the previous administration.
abrogate.word_example: It was quickly  abrogated with one rewrite after another, each resulting in further land take-aways from the Sioux.

forsake.word_example: For most of us, choosing family doesn’t mean  forsaking our friends or core beliefs.
forsake.word_definition: leave someone who needs or counts on you; leave in the lurch

Change Your Mind.list_detailed_description: A person is entitled to change their mind. Sometimes, however, this switch can be seen as a betrayal to the people you used to side with and have now left behind. Opinions or deeply held beliefs help make a person who they are, and an entire vocabulary has arisen based on changes of heart because of how fundamental certain viewpoints seem. Here are ten words about changing your mind.

Super Bowl Blowout: Dull Game, Epic Voca.list_brief_description: Super Bowls don't always live up to the hype. But even if the game itself is boring, the words used to describe it are exciting.

demolish.word_example: The Huskies  demolished the Beavers 87-61 two weeks ago and hope to repeat that rare stellar performance at 8 p.m.

lopsided.word_description: This word originally referred to ships that were bigger or heavier on one side, which doesn’t sound like a recipe for staying afloat.
lopsided.word_example: It tied for the most  lopsided victory this season for Stanford.
lopsided.word_definition: having one side lower or smaller or lighter than the other

annihilate.word_description: Geek alert: There is a comic book villain named Annihilus, whose hobby is not knitting.
annihilate.word_example: Oklahoma  annihilated Kansas State last year, but the Wildcats have won two straight in Norman.

pummel.word_example: The Raiders  pummeled Laurel on Tuesday and DuVal on Friday to stay unbeaten against Prince George’s County competition.

blowout.word_description: This word originally referred to angry quarrels that likely involved blowhards.
blowout.word_example: Those  blowouts led to a classic Super Bowl, though, won by Pittsburgh, 35-31.

expose.word_example: Left tackle Nate Solder said the vulnerabilities that were  exposed last week by the Texans isn’t always a bad thing.

trounce.word_example: They  trounced the Seattle Seahawks and advanced to a home playoff game against the Giants.
trounce.word_definition: come out better in a competition, race, or conflict

blitz.word_description: When comedian George Carlin compared football and war, this word was exhibit A.
blitz.word_example: The Giants’ defense was energetic and disruptive, bottling up an explosive offense with aggressive  blitzes.
blitz.word_definition: defensive players try to break through the offensive line

clobber.word_example: In its three previous games this season against ranked teams, the Huskies  clobbered then-No.
clobber.word_definition: defeat thoroughly and conclusively in a competition or fight

crush.word_example: For the Cowboys, that last startling completion by Rodgers helped bring a  crushing end to a sterling season.
crush.word_definition: come out better in a competition, race, or conflict

decimate.word_example: Kiko Alonso is the only linebacker certain to return, and a secondary  decimated by injuries needs attention.

wallop.word_description: This was originally a word for something it rhymed with: a horse’s gallop.
wallop.word_example: His favorite game was probably 1935, four years before Union Station opened, when Alabama, one of the best teams he’s ever seen,  walloped Stanford.

thrash.word_description: It’s fitting that thrash rhymes with crash and smash.
thrash.word_example: “It was almost breathtaking,” he said of that Fiesta Bowl scene when Utah  thrashed Pitt, 35-7.

embarrass.word_description: The idea here is that a lousy team was masquerading as a good one. In a similar vein, sometimes people say a team that’s been exposed or embarrassed has been undressed.
embarrass.word_example: After an  embarrassing 27-point loss to Albany, do the Retrievers run laps or just get a light rolled-up newspaper tap on their noses?

dominate.word_description: With its short, sharp sound, drub almost sound like the pounding it represents.
dominate.word_example: The game was  dominated by the defenses, which frustrated most of the game’s drives on both sides.

rout.word_example: He was Seattle’s defensive coordinator during back-to-back Super Bowl appearances - one a  rout of the Broncos, the other a heartbreaking loss to the Patriots.

victimize.word_example: The third-string goalie was  victimized by some bad fortune and some defensive breakdowns.
victimize.word_definition: cause someone to suffer some adverse circumstance

The Sweltering Words of Summer.list_brief_description: Looking for a variety of words to choose from when complaining about how hot it is? You're in luck! There are plenty of ways to gripe about just how stifling th...

muggy.word_description: Muggy has been around since at least the 1700s. Another word used for humid or muggy weather is  sticky, in reference to the sweat-soaked shirts and other garments that can make summer so uncomfortable. It's one thing to be sweaty after playing basketball or ripping phone books. It's another thing to be drenched in sweat just standing there, because of monumental mugginess.
muggy.word_example: The ocean breeze swept away the  muggy heat of the summer afternoon, and it was pleasantly cool under the shade of the palmetto trees.

blistering.word_definition: hot enough to raise (or as if to raise) blisters
blistering.word_example: After a weekend of  blistering heat, firefighters will face additional weather-related complications, according to the National Weather Service.

humid.word_definition: containing or characterized by a great deal of water vapor
humid.word_description: One of the most annoying summer phrases—along with "Hot enough for ya?"—is "It's not the heat, it's the humidity." When humidity is high, the weather is  humid. High humidity means there's a lot of moisture in the air, and when humidity reaches 100%, Mother Nature makes it rain.
humid.word_example: “For example, in a warming world, we anticipate more unbearably  humid days,” he said.

oppressive.word_definition: weighing heavily on the senses or spirit
oppressive.word_description: This word usually refers to tyrannical governments that crush their people's spirits. Anything oppressive pushes down from above, which may explain why people often describe the heat as  oppressive when the sun feels like the enemy, because it's just so flippin' hot. If the heat is oppressive, it's wearing down your body and spirit. Seek an air conditioner immediately.
oppressive.word_example: But 50 years ago she was a pre-teen, sleeping on the porch to escape the  oppressive heat, awakening to see a sky that glowed unnaturally.

nuclear.word_definition: deriving destructive energy from releasing atomic energy
nuclear.word_description: Literally, anything nuclear refers to the nucleus of an atom. Nuclear energy comes from splitting the atom, and that's why you see references to nuclear weapons, nuclear power plants, and nuclear scientists. However, sometimes this term is used a bit more loosely. When an argument gets out of hand, it goes nuclear, and when the temperatures rise to preposterous degrees, you can say the weather has also reached nuclear levels.
nuclear.word_example: A  nuclear summer almost assuredly is on the way.

balmy.word_example: On a  balmy summer evening with a breeze to keep the bugs away, it’s perfectly enchanting.

tropical.word_description: This refers to countries around the Earth's equator: the tropics. These areas, far from the chilly North and South poles, have the opposite weather: hot and steamy. This is why tropical nations such as Jamaica and the Bahamas are popular vacation spots, and it's also why  tropical is a synonym for hot weather.
tropical.word_example: Drivers sling hammocks in their wheel wells and sometimes wait several days in the thick  tropical heat.

sweltering.word_definition: excessively hot and humid; marked by sweating and faintness
sweltering.word_description: Since the 1600s,  sweltering has been a word for excessive heat. The Oxford English Dictionary describes it as, "Oppressive or overpowering with great heat; causing or accompanied by profuse sweating or suffocation through extreme heat." That's right: sweltering heat is so bad you might not even be able to breathe, literally. Sweltering isn't swell.
sweltering.word_example: Plus, it was  sweltering and one groomsman wanted to shed his suit jacket.

stifling.word_definition: characterized by oppressive heat and humidity
stifling.word_example: Arizona is seeing the most  stifling temperatures, but the wrath of the heat wave is being felt across Nevada and California as well.

scorch.word_definition: become singed under intense heat or dry conditions
scorch.word_example: This weekend, despite  scorching temperatures, they contained the majority of the 20 more significant wildfires at a few thousand acres.

The Sweltering Words of Summer.list_detailed_description: Looking for a variety of words to choose from when complaining about how hot it is? You're in luck! There are plenty of ways to gripe about just how stifling the summer months can be.

Gregg Allman (1947-2017) Tribute List.list_brief_description: Southern Rock pioneer Gregg Allman died on May 28, 2017 at the age of 69. With his Allman Brothers Band, Gregg used wailing guitar and lyrics about gambling and...

rejoice.word_example: As they say in the bible, that you're supposed to  rejoice when people die and mourn when they're born, because it's one of the most painful acts you go through in life, is being born, and dying.

desperation.word_example: Letters unanswered and visits so few
desperation.word_definition: a state in which all hope is lost or absent

obliged.word_definition: under a moral obligation to do something

anticipate.word_example: She sits there waiting,  anticipating his return,

prowl.word_example: Well I am on the  prowl, baby
prowl.word_definition: move about in or as if in a predatory manner

bayou.word_example: I'm on my way to New Orleans this mornin',
bayou.word_definition: a swampy arm or slow-moving outlet of a lake

absurd.word_example: Your wasted words so  absurd, are you really Satan, yes or no?
absurd.word_definition: inconsistent with reason or logic or common sense

burden.word_example: Sweet mama, lay your  burden down,
burden.word_definition: weight to be borne or conveyed

toll.word_example: Oh but his luck will change... time takes it's  toll
toll.word_definition: value measured by what must be done to obtain something

ghetto.word_example: Don't care if I'm a big star
ghetto.word_definition: a poor densely populated city district

Gregg Allman (1947-2017) Tribute List.list_detailed_description: Southern Rock pioneer Gregg Allman died on May 28, 2017 at the age of 69. With his Allman Brothers Band, Gregg used wailing guitar and lyrics about gambling and relationships gone bad to define both his persona as a "bad boy" of rock and roll and an entire genre of music. Here are ten vocabulary words drawn from the lyrics of Gregg Allman.

The Smashing Lexicon of Tennis.list_brief_description: Let’s look at some tennis words, which won’t help your stroke but will boost your vocabulary. For the full article, check out: Tennis, Anyone?

lob.word_definition: an easy return of a tennis ball in a high arc
lob.word_example: Murray used plenty of drop shots and  lobs, often to great effect.

smash.word_definition: hit (a tennis ball) in a powerful overhead stroke
smash.word_description: To smash something is to destroy it utterly. It’s no accident that destructive antihero the Hulk’s catchphrase is “Hulk smash!” In tennis,
smash.word_example: Frustration boiled over for the Swiss in the second set after he misfired with an overhead  smash.

ace.word_definition: a serve that the receiver is unable to reach
ace.word_example: "I think my game today was much better, especially my serve," said Pliskova, who pounded 13  aces past her opponent.

fault.word_definition: an imperfection in an object or machine
fault.word_description: A fault is some kind of defect or mistake. If you spilled a drink, and then someone slipped on it, that was your fault. Also, everyone has faults in the sense of traits that aren’t the best. In tennis, the meaning of fault is more specific: an error made while serving. If your serve hits the net, even a little bit, that’s a fault, and you need to serve again. If you hit the net again, that’s a double fault, which results in a point for the other player.
fault.word_example: Williams saved a break point for 5-4, paying no heed to the applause that greeted her double  fault and a butchered drive volley.

stroke.word_example: Both finalists rely on uncomplicated games of big serving and ground  strokes.

clay.word_description: Breaking refers to many sorts of destruction, but in tennis you’ve broken your opponent if you win the game when they’re serving.
clay.word_example: Unlike the other grand slams that are played on cement or  clay, Wimbledon's courts are alive.

volley.word_definition: a tennis return made by hitting the ball before it bounces
volley.word_example: Williams saved a break point for 5-4, paying no heed to the applause that greeted her double fault and a butchered drive  volley.

deuce.word_definition: tie requiring winning two successive points to win the game
deuce.word_example: After fighting through  deuce, he struck a forehand long to hand Nadal his fifth break of the match at 1-4 in the third.

match.word_definition: a formal contest in which people or teams compete
match.word_description: This is a word that applies to many situations that involve one plus one. If your shirt and pants go together, they match. If you meet the person you want to marry, you met your perfect match. In sports, a one-on-one contest is called a match. Tennis commentators talk about match play (singles matches) as opposed to doubles (teams of two playing each other).
match.word_example: Muguruza broke her again to open the second set and faced only two break points during the entire  match.
