Words That Put You To Work.list_brief_description: Labor Day is a time to recognize those who toil in this country, slog through their expected tasks, and simply work hard. It's also a time to enjoy the waning d...

wage.word_example: Many low-wage workers in the Gateway City will lose raises they received in May, when the minimum  wage increased to $10 an hour.

salary.word_example: The government is set to reveal whether companies should publish their pay ratio - the  salary gap between their executives and wider workforce.

industrious.word_definition: characterized by hard work and perseverance
industrious.word_description: No word better exemplifies the bright side of labor than this word, which means inventive, resourceful and clever. Being
industrious.word_example: It is entirely reasonable for every  industrious and diligent person in our society to expect access to dignified, important and adequately compensated work.

productive.word_definition: capable of bringing forth, especially abundantly
productive.word_example: In his Tuesday statement, Tillerson said Washington was interested in a “ productive dialogue” but only on the basis of Pyongyang’s acceptance of nuclear disarmament.

diligence.word_definition: conscientiousness in paying proper attention to a task
diligence.word_description: To work with a sense of
diligence.word_example: "This new outbreak is being handled with extreme care,  diligence and with the experience gained from the first outbreak," said Astral in a statement.

efficient.word_definition: being effective without wasting time, effort, or expense
efficient.word_example: At a fleet and  efficient 81 minutes — several minutes shorter than its original running time — “Kidnap” is an action movie with barely a wasted frame.

labor.word_definition: any piece of work that is undertaken or attempted
labor.word_description: Any manual or physical activity that is not done for fun can be called a
labor.word_example: The government also launched the  labor reforms that were central to Macron’s campaign promise to boost France’s lagging economy through pro-free market policies.

assiduous.word_definition: marked by care and persistent effort
assiduous.word_example: A spokeswoman for UKA said the email highlighted just how  assiduous the organisation is in ensuring that classification is done fairly and robustly.

drudgery.word_example: But a washing machine is clean and efficient and replaces work that was always  drudgery.

slog.word_definition: walk heavily and firmly, as when weary, or through mud
slog.word_example: What followed was a months-long  slog as the two sides, pitted against one another, failed to agree on a way forward.

conscientious.word_definition: characterized by extreme care and great effort
conscientious.word_example: “They were brilliant, really nice people, so  conscientious and courteous,” he said.

toil.word_example: Klopp’s side frequently faced, and  toiled against, opponents who sat back en masse and played on the counterattack last season.

employment.word_definition: the state of having a job
employment.word_example: Conditions are unsanitary and there is little to no access to healthcare, education or  employment.

Words That Put You To Work.list_detailed_description: Labor Day is a time to recognize those who

April Fool's List.list_brief_description: In celebration of April Fool's Day, here are twenty vocabulary words that all have to do with various degrees of joking, trickery and deceit. Some involve a sim...

gullible.word_example: Lawyers for the brokers said the men didn’t actually help Mr. Hayes and instead were simply telling the  gullible trader what he wanted to hear.
gullible.word_definition: naive and easily deceived or tricked

swindle.word_example: Last year, he allegedly  swindled some two dozen people by selling them — for cash — phony pilgrimages to see Pope Francis in Philadelphia.

risible.word_example: How do you write a play about the British royal family without making its members seem  risible, banal or irrelevant?

buffoon.word_description: In the 1500s, this word evolved from a French word for a jester: buffoons paid the bills by making jokes, juggling balls, and performing other lowbrow feats. Nowadays a buffoon is just a doofus.
buffoon.word_example: Advertisers can make galleries, whereas you and I still have to post every photo individually like  buffoons.
buffoon.word_definition: a person who amuses others by ridiculous behavior

idiot.word_description: The always popular term  idiot has had a wild history, sliding between slang, medicine, and the law.
idiot.word_example: In January I deleted all the social media apps from my phone because they were turning me into an  idiot.

bluff.word_example: It’s hard to see how his style would fit in political or diplomatic negotiations, where compromise is necessary and  bluffing is dangerous.
bluff.word_definition: pretense that your position is stronger than it really is

gull.word_example: He keeps trying to  gull the gullible by pretending that his financial statement at the Federal Election Commission is more revealing than his taxes.
gull.word_definition: make a fool or dupe of

mendacious.word_example: No one should be surprised if Russian forces renew their offensive in the coming days, while Moscow’s  mendacious propaganda apparatus blames Ukraine.

dupe.word_example: “They paid the money. And then they found out it was a scam. They were upset. And they feel  duped.”

hoax.word_example: Police say they knew it was a  hoax, but they took Armaan into custody because he confessed to making up the threat.

comedian.word_description: This is a professional joke-teller—often called a  standup comedian.
comedian.word_example: This 160-seat space is where local  comedians, dancers, thespians and composers flock to share their talents.

bamboozle.word_example: Along the way GhostSecGroup has  bamboozled the press, which is unfortunate, because it’s not clear that GhostSecGroup knows what it’s doing.

jest.word_description: To jest is to joke, though  jest sounds fairly archaic these days. A person who jests is a jester: a rare word for the butt of a jester’s jibes is  jestee.
jest.word_example: The parties involved in the exchange told investigators they were just joking, and those investigators concluded the messages were written in  jest.

cunning.word_description: To trick someone on April Fool’s Day, you have to be cunning. This is a word to describe the tricky and sly.
cunning.word_example: That sort of obfuscation may be a  cunning way to sell used cars.

hoodwink.word_example: Somehow, the advertising industry has  hoodwinked us into thinking that we have to drop everything today and make purchases or … or what?

cozen.word_example: I could forgive him had he not tricked you and deceived you,  cozened you and flattered you--into this!

delude.word_example: Don’t  delude yourself that you will one day get him to “see the light” and come around to your point of view.

quip.word_example: “Good clothes open doors,” Welch  quipped when asked the best bit of style advice she ever received.

April Fool's List.list_detailed_description: In celebration of April Fool's Day, here are twenty vocabulary words that all have to do with various degrees of joking, trickery and deceit. Some involve a simple lie or two, while others indicate elaborate schemes. For more on the history of these words, read

Memorial Day: Words of Respect and Remem.list_brief_description: Here’s a look at some of the words you’re most likely to hear and see around Memorial Day. There are many ways to honor the people who died in combat for th...

memorial.word_description: The name of this holiday is a word closely related to  memory. Memorials—such as the famous Lincoln Memorial—are there to help us remember people who died. There are memorials for all sorts of people, but memorials to veterans get a little extra respect, and for good reason. One of the most famous (and largest) memorials in the U.S. is the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, which is two acres long and contains the names of everyone who died in that war.
memorial.word_example: The three officers to be honored died in past years, and were recently added to the National Law Enforcement  Memorial.
memorial.word_definition: a structure erected to commemorate persons or events

platoon.word_description: This French borrowing entered English in the 1500s: it refers to a group of soldiers, usually infantrymen. Often a platoon is made of various squadrons or squads—a platoon is bigger than a squad, but smaller than a company. Soldiers who served in the same platoon share a special bond.
platoon.word_example: He led a rifle  platoon in Vietnam, eventually receiving numerous commendations, including the Purple Heart and the Bronze Star.
platoon.word_definition: a military unit that is a subdivision of a company

service.word_description: This common word has a specific military meaning that's a lot more important than the service you get at your local pizzeria. When you enter the military, you've entered the  service, and you can call your time there  military service. Many people say to veterans, "Thank you for your service." The idea is that joining the military isn't something you do for yourself, like becoming a lawyer or artist, but something done to serve your country.
service.word_example: No one now outside of the War Department knew the quality and duration of his  service.
service.word_definition: an act of help or assistance

deferment.word_example: Trump himself received five draft  deferments during the Vietnam War, including one for bone spurs in his heel, the Times reported in August.
deferment.word_definition: act of putting off to a future time

sacrifice.word_description: To sacrifice something is to give it up, and this is one of the most important words relating to Memorial Day, which honors people who sacrificed their lives. Dying in war is often called the  ultimate sacrifice. In a world where most people are all about me, me, and me, this type of sacrifice is hard to imagine.
sacrifice.word_example: The  sacrifice of soldiers killed during World Wars One and Two is well-documented.
sacrifice.word_definition: personnel that are lost by death or capture

enlist.word_description: A draft brings people into the military, whether they want to join or not. The U.S. has had a draft at different points in history, most recently during the Vietnam era when we were sending an enormous number of troops over there. Whether there's a draft or not, people can volunteer for the military: if you volunteer, you enlist. This word can also be used to describe recruiting other people. A new enlistee in the navy could then try to enlist others: in other words, encourage them to join too.
enlist.word_example: He thought about  enlisting in the Marine Corps before an encounter with a CIA recruiter.

draft.word_description: There are many types of drafts, such as a gust of wind or rough piece of writing. But the military version is a lot more significant: a draft selects people for the military. If you're drafted, you have to enter the service, unless you don't pass the medical exams. Some people receive a  deferment, meaning they delay their service. Another way that some avoid the draft is by being a conscientious objector: someone philosophically opposed to violence in general or a specific war.
draft.word_example: 366 blue plastic capsules contained the birthdays that would be chosen in the first Vietnam  draft lottery drawing on December 1, 1969.

troop.word_example: In January 2016, South Korean border  troops fired shots at a suspected drone.

combat.word_example: But Pentagon officials this month maintained that the accident occurred outside the Vietnam  combat zone.
combat.word_definition: the act of fighting; any contest or struggle

military.word_description: The military consists of the army, the navy, the marines, and all other government forces that go to war. General, captain, private, and ensign are all military ranks. The military's goal is to defend the county, but also to attack other countries when ordered. A frequently debated political topic is military spending: how much money should be spent on tanks, planes, bombs, and other military equipment? Some argue for a stronger military, while others will say more money should go elsewhere.
military.word_example: The  military did not say whether there were any US casualties during the raid which was supported by the Yemeni government.
military.word_definition: the armed forces of a nation

compulsory.word_example: Russia maintains the  compulsory one-year draft, but has increasingly sought to enlist volunteers for longer terms of duty to boost the military capability.

strategy.word_example: Lee, they wrote, mishandled overall  strategy of the war.
strategy.word_definition: an elaborate and systematic plan of action

veteran.word_description: A veteran is anyone who has served in some branch of the military such as the army, navy, air force, or marines. No matter how long someone served, they're a veteran. This word is also used for other types of experience, especially substantial experience. A teacher who's been chalking boards for decades can be called a veteran teacher. A basketball player who's been in the NBA for a while—say, 5-10 years—is often called a veteran. And if you've done anything for some time, this word can apply.
veteran.word_example: Included in the executive’s proposal would be an exemption for low-income seniors and disabled  veterans.
veteran.word_definition: a person who has served in the armed forces

volunteer.word_example: Bereza, who commanded one of the  volunteer battalions that fought in the east, called it necessary to preserve the state.
volunteer.word_definition: a person who performs work done by choice

Memorial Day: Words of Respect and Remem.list_detailed_description: Here’s a look at some of the words you’re most likely to hear and see around Memorial Day. There are many ways to honor the people who died in combat for their country: one is to understand their vocabulary.

Trumps.list_brief_description: What does it mean to trump or have a trump? Find out through this list of synonymous verbs and nouns.

trump.word_description: The Old French "tromper" means both "to blow a trumpet" and "to deceive." This connection comes from quacks who used to blow a trumpet in order to attract the public and convince them to buy their fake cures.
trump.word_example: The Constitution states that federal law is “the supreme law of the land,”  trumping state constitutions when they conflict with the federal constitution.

precedence.word_example: "They should not give  precedence to money. Money is not the first issue. Humans are the first issue. We are not numbers; we are humans."
precedence.word_definition: status established in order of importance or urgency

prevalence.word_example: Given the  prevalence of negative ads, many stock photo searches by political campaigns are actually for photos of their opponents.
prevalence.word_definition: a superiority in numbers or amount

expediency.word_example: Political  expediency and the passing of time may prevent anyone from ever knowing for sure.
expediency.word_definition: the quality of being suited to the end in view

influence.word_example: Election Day was a reminder of Twitter’s  influence in media and the distribution of information.
influence.word_definition: a power to affect persons or events

authority.word_example: I always respected their  authority and considered them my president.
authority.word_definition: the power or right to give orders or make decisions

supremacy.word_example: Any account of the Klan’s disturbing legacy rightfully centers on the deadly acts of violence its members have perpetrated in the name of white  supremacy.

surpass.word_example: More than 34 million Americans have already voted,  surpassing the 32 million who cast their ballots early four years ago.
surpass.word_definition: be or do something to a greater degree

sanction.word_example: When it comes to turning down a renewal petition, the school district must chose a reason  sanctioned by state law.

eminence.word_example: In addition to celebrating the presidential nominee, national conventions are a showcase for party  eminences, rising stars and elected officials.
eminence.word_definition: high status importance owing to marked superiority

leverage.word_example: They have little  leverage over their communities, but some believe in pushing for change through political engagement.
leverage.word_definition: strategic advantage; power to act effectively

profit.word_example: These billionaires have pumped billions into creating a new privatized school system where those running schools can  profit and evade government oversight.

asset.word_example: The dollar also recouped some ground, while  assets that many investors search out at times of uncertainty, such as gold, came off earlier highs.

dominance.word_example: Dominance in Congress is seen as being crucial to the next president's prospects of turning policy plans into law.
dominance.word_definition: the state when one person or group has power over another

preference.word_example: Fewer than half of voters who cast presidential ballots say they made their choice out of a strong  preference for their candidate.
preference.word_definition: grant of favor or advantage to one over another

resource.word_example: “It’s all part of doing as much good as we can with the  resources we have.”
resource.word_definition: aid or support that may be drawn upon when needed

prestige.word_example: The resulting fears and discontents undermined the credibility and  prestige of existing leaders and doctrines.
prestige.word_definition: a high standing achieved through success or influence

finesse.word_example: That dynamic gives them license to adopt a take-no-prisoners form of politics antithetical to the political  finesse typically required to pass legislation.
finesse.word_definition: subtly skillful handling of a situation

mastery.word_example: All major European states imposed colonial  mastery over Africa and Asia.

convenience.word_example: For  convenience, ballots are distributed when residents arrive.
convenience.word_definition: the state of being suitable or opportune

superiority.word_example: Educated v less educated may be even more toxic than rich v poor, because it comes laden with assumptions of moral  superiority.
superiority.word_definition: the quality of being better than someone or something

defeat.word_example: In 1948, the Chicago Tribune incorrectly reported that Thomas Dewey had  defeated Harry Truman in the presidential election.

ascendancy.word_example: There are struggles for power as new groups gain political  ascendancy and older groups, once a majority, become minorities.
ascendancy.word_definition: the state when one person or group has power over another

triumph.word_description: "Trump" could be an alteration of "triumph." This meaning is suggested by card games in which trumps rank above the other suits.
triumph.word_example: There is no more Cold War, as the United States and its allies  triumphed over the Soviet Union.

gratification.word_example: The world at large, and the United States in particular, has developed an unfortunate need for instant  gratification.

Trumps.list_detailed_description: What does it mean to trump or have a trump? Find out through this list of synonymous verbs and nouns.

Motherlode: A Mother's Day Lexicon.list_brief_description: Mothers do so many things, which is why a good nap may be the best gift you can give your own mom on Mother's Day. Still, you might want to offer Mom a few word...

protect.word_description: Motherhood isn't just about feeding and clothing: moms protect their young, as you can find out for yourself by messing with a baby bear in the wild. Moms protect their kids from suspicious strangers, inappropriate TV shows, and bad decisions, like a toddler who thinks he can jump off the top of the couch and stick the landing. Moms are, in their own way, the most caring bodyguards in the world.
protect.word_example: When she had asked me what I was going to say, I told her, “I’m going to  protect my own . . . you know how it is.
protect.word_definition: shield from danger, injury, destruction, or damage

nourish.word_description: Whether through breastfeeding, bottles, or ordering a pizza, mothers nourish their children. The first meanings of this word applied to breastfeeding, but the word has broadened quite a bit. You can call any food nourishment, and you can even call some non-edible things nourishing. For example, a great book is nourishment for your mind. But as your mother would say, "Never, ever eat books."
nourish.word_example: Rachel worried that her daughter did not gain, and fussed over the fire concocting  nourishing stews which Mercy obediently tried to swallow.

console.word_description: Consoling is similar to soothing. When you console someone, you make them feel better with kind words such as "You'll do better on the next math test" or "Here, have a cookie." Mothers have a lot of consoling to do, since children are constantly getting their knees scraped by the pavement and their dreams crushed by the world. Even as kids turn into adults, they still usually turn to their moms for consolation.
console.word_example: I don’t need to be patted or  consoled, like a child.
console.word_definition: give moral or emotional strength to

raise.word_example: Whether a woman parents her child as her mother  raised her, or adopts a different style, becoming a mother provides an opportunity for a do-over.

vex.word_description: As great as your mom is—and hey, I never said she wasn't, so relax—I bet she sometimes vexes you. This is a short, punchy, useful word for irritations. Mothers constantly worry about their children, so they tend to nag them—nagging is one of the top ten vexations in the universe. Vex has been a word since at least the 1400s, and it can be used in two ways. If someone is annoying you, you can say "Stop vexing me!" or "I am vexed!" Vexing is a two-way street, but both are a pain in the tuchus.
vex.word_example: His mother would be  vexed to see him gulp his malted milk or bolt his sandwich.

soothe.word_description: Mothers often soothe their children, especially little ones who start crying because they're hungry, they have to go to the bathroom, they're tired, or it's Wednesday. I have a friend with three small children, and she spends most of the day soothing. The origins of this word are surprising: soothing had to do with proving something true rather than making someone feel better. Soothe was related to soothsayer, someone who speaks the truth and is therefore hard to find these days.
soothe.word_example: I let her hold and  soothe me like a little child, until I fell asleep.

encourage.word_example: She also  encouraged her daughter’s natural musical talent by enrolling her in piano lessons.

foster.word_example: Additionally, Matheus said, the agency realized it needed to offer additional support for  foster parents.
foster.word_definition: providing nurture though not related by blood or legal ties

cajole.word_example: I resent being forced to spend my limited time with my son  cajoling him to do mindless worksheets.
cajole.word_definition: influence or urge by gentle urging, caressing, or flattering

nurture.word_example: “We’re there to  nurture them, and we should not be asked to spurn a child’s affection.”

beget.word_description: This word, best known for its use in the Bible, is something all biological mothers can put on their resume: they begat, to use the past tense. To beget is to have children: begetting is reproducing. This old Germanic word doesn't pop up too often these days, though it is useful in jokes.
beget.word_example: Along with this, self-preservation and development and reproduction, the  begetting of offspring of like nature, are characteristic.

guide.word_example: Roy figured she used up her  guiding skills every day at school and was too worn out to deal with Garrett when she got home.
guide.word_definition: be a motivating force or drive

worry.word_example: His mother would be  worried sick once she realized he was out in this weather.

Motherlode: A Mother's Day Lexicon.list_detailed_description: Mothers do so many things, which is why a good nap may be the best gift you can give your own mom on Mother's Day. Still, you might want to offer Mom a few words of appreciation, so here's a list of 13 verbs that get to the heart of what mothers do.

Book Words for Book Worms.list_brief_description: There's more to books than just reading them. Books have a whole vocabulary associated with them that designates parts of books, kinds of books, people involved...

author.word_example: Although such frantic commercial output led to uneven quality, Cooper sketched career blueprints for ambitious American  authors who followed him.

epilogue.word_definition: a short passage added at the end of a literary work
epilogue.word_example: From there the novel veers into an  epilogue set many years in the future, following the collapse of Gilead.

amanuensis.word_definition: someone skilled in the transcription of speech
amanuensis.word_description: In the days before dictation software, in fact before software of any kind at all, there was the amanuensis. An amanuensis is someone who writes down everything that is said. Often it is easier for someone not used to being a writer to speak their thoughts aloud. The amanuensis captures this free-flowing speech on the page, so it can then be organized and edited into a finished work.
amanuensis.word_example: My  amanuensis sits at the table, and I sit near him, or lie on the sofa, and dictate the stories which I publish.”

volume.word_definition: a collection of written or printed sheets bound together
volume.word_example: At the time of his death in 1851, at age 62, he was envisioning a  volume about the past and future of New York City.

devour.word_example: A third, set largely in the Louvre, is a breathless thriller readers will  devour on a long flight.

prologue.word_example: In the  prologue to “Romeo and Juliet,” the chorus tells the audience that the tale will unfold within “the two hours’ traffic of our stage.”

bibliophile.word_definition: someone who loves and usually collects books
bibliophile.word_example: She ends up at Scroll, a company whose mission is “to reinvent reading the way Starbucks reinvented coffee” by creating lounges for  bibliophiles.

enchant.word_definition: cast a spell over someone or something
enchant.word_example: Religion aside, Wittenberg’s picture-perfect backdrop and upbeat, Renaissance spirit is enough to  enchant those without the slightest interest in the Reformer .

tome.word_example: Some readers will be aghast that chapters end with bullet-point summaries and questions, evoking the worst of unctuous business  tomes.

inspiration.word_definition: arousal of the mind to unusual activity or creativity
inspiration.word_example: He was very clear about the  inspiration for the house of his eponymous novel – Rooks Nest, his childhood home.

A Graduation Lexicon.list_brief_description: Congraduations may be cute, but it's not a real word. Here are fifteen real words often seen and heard in the days before and after a graduation ceremony, hidde...

ceremony.word_description: Graduation isn’t just about finishing high school: it’s all about the ceremony, which is a type of ritual involving specific traditions. Graduates have to wear a tent-like robe, put on a strange cap (called a  mortarboard), and receive their diploma from the principal in front of the whole school. The graduation is a theatrical event meant to celebrate this major event in your life.
ceremony.word_example: The graduation  ceremony is scheduled to begin 10 a.m.
ceremony.word_definition: a formal event performed on a special occasion

congratulations.word_description: This word is one of the happiest word in English, and it’s one of the most commonly heard at graduation time. Some people even get cute and say  congraduations.
congratulations.word_example: “I was actually very surprised, people all around the world contacted me, offering me  congratulations for getting into these schools.”
congratulations.word_definition: an expression of approval and commendation

attendance.word_description: Some people are a little shy about big ceremonies, so they don’t attend graduation, meaning they don’t show up. Fortunately, attendance is a lot more important before graduation than during. There’s an old cliché that has some truth to it:  Half of life is just showing up. That’s what teachers generally think when it comes to attendance: being present for something, in that case, class. If you don’t attend most of your classes, you won't even have the option of attending graduation.
attendance.word_example: There’s mandatory kindergarten in several states, while Pennsylvania and Washington don’t require  attendance until age 8.
attendance.word_definition: the frequency with which a person is present

university.word_description: There's an old saying, "When one door closes, another door opens." So even though graduation is about the end of high school, it also means many students will be going on to a college or university: in either case, an institution of higher learning. The main difference between a college and university has to do with what the faculty are up to: universities produce more research than colleges, which are more focused on teaching.
university.word_definition: an institution of higher learning that grants degrees

valedictorian.word_description: Graduating with honors is impressive, but there’s an even greater honor: to be the  valedictorian. This is the student with the best grades in the entire school. Not much looks better on a college application that being valedictorian of your high-school class. The valedictorian is usually asked to speak during commencement: this is sometimes called a  valedictory address.
valedictorian.word_example: They whooped and cheered for the 19-year-old, who GWU said in a news release is expected to be his class  valedictorian.
valedictorian.word_definition: the student with the best grades

diploma.word_description: This is what it's all about — getting that official piece of paper that says you've made it.
diploma.word_example: She received a high school  diploma from the jail’s charter school, enrolled in college courses and wrote poetry and an autobiography.
diploma.word_definition: a document certifying the completion of a course of study

honor.word_description: In high school, students who make really good grades end up on the  honor roll, which can lead to graduating with honors. Very good students might also get the chance to take  honors classes: smaller, special classes designed for students who are a little more talented and/or motivated than average. There are also honors classes in college, and getting into any such class is an honor: in other words, a distinction and privilege.
honor.word_example: After graduating with  honors from Michigan State University’s James Madison College, Robb wrote a biography about his famous father.
honor.word_definition: a tangible symbol signifying approval or distinction

relative.word_description: When you graduate from high school, it’s a great accomplishment, and your family is going to want to celebrate. That means you might have all sorts of  relatives show up.  Relative is, pardon the expression, a relatively broad term, covering everyone from parents and siblings to fifth cousins, great-aunts, and great-great-grandmothers. If someone is part of your family, they’re a relative — even if they’re not related by blood.
relative.word_example: More than 50  relatives, friends and co-workers are expected to attend Monday’s ceremony.
relative.word_definition: a person connected by blood or marriage

salutatorian.word_example: To decrease competition, there are no class rankings and no valedictorians and  salutatorians.
salutatorian.word_definition: a graduating student with the second highest academic rank

address.word_description: This square cap is probably the most characteristic piece of graduation clothing.
address.word_example: It was supposed to be their big day and their last chance to  address the 2017 graduating class of Oxon Hill High School.

graduate.word_example: The gainful employment rule was designed to ensure that  graduates would be able to earn enough money to pay off their student loan debt.
graduate.word_definition: a person who has received a degree from a school

commencement.word_description: When something  commences, it begins. The sense of graduation as a new beginning is why a graduation ceremony is also known as  commencement. You don’t hear variations of  commence much outside of schools, but if you wanted to sound very official (and maybe a little pompous) you could start a meal or game of Pictionary by saying, “Let us commence!”
commencement.word_example: Before college seniors toss their caps in the air at graduation, they're often counseled about the future through the time-honored tradition of  commencement speeches.
commencement.word_definition: an academic exercise in which diplomas are conferred

principal.word_description: The master of ceremonies at graduation is usually the principal: the person in charge of a school, like a president is in charge of a country or a CEO is in charge of a company. A classic sign of being in trouble is getting called to the principal's office. Most schools also have assistant principals or vice principals. All the other staff, plus the teachers and students, must answer to the principal, but the principal has to answer to the superintendent and the school district.
principal.word_example: The student's parents are due to meet with the high school  principal and yearbook adviser this week.
principal.word_definition: the educator who has executive authority for a school

An Inspirational Back-to-School Word Lis.list_brief_description: As you pack your backpack and sharpen your pencils, take a moment to sharpen your vocabulary! Here are ten words that can inspire you to take on the academic ch...

reflection.word_example: When they do something, whether it’s good or bad, they take time for  reflection.

character.word_example: “You wouldn’t see the rich, unique  character that shines through.”
character.word_definition: attributes that determine one's moral and ethical actions

wisdom.word_example: But researchers pointed to some likely explanations -- including the perspective and " wisdom" that comes from life experience.
wisdom.word_definition: accumulated knowledge or erudition or enlightenment

stamina.word_example: Underwater for about two-thirds of each performance, synchronized swimmers require  stamina, flexibility, endurance and, always, poise.

potential.word_example: Giving children a fair chance to achieve their dreams and reach their  potential is everyone's responsibility.
potential.word_definition: the inherent capacity for coming into being

exuberance.word_example: There were historic performances by some of the world’s greatest athletes, cheered on – and sometimes booed – by crowds exhibiting Brazil’s characteristic  exuberance.

fortitude.word_example: “It just takes  fortitude. It takes bravery,” Gatlin said of the young sprinters.
fortitude.word_definition: strength of mind that enables one to endure adversity

rigor.word_example: So Victor tries to do as much as a college junior immersed in the  rigors of schoolwork and major-college football can do.

achievement.word_example: “This  achievement is a testament to the hard work and dedication of employees across the federal government,” Rice said.

inspiration.word_example: One young girl said: "Amy is an  inspiration, she's shown us what can be done. She worked really hard, she deserves what she's got."
inspiration.word_definition: arousal of the mind to unusual activity or creativity

An Inspirational Back-to-School Word Lis.list_detailed_description: As you pack your backpack and sharpen your pencils, take a moment to sharpen your vocabulary! Here are ten words that can inspire you to take on the academic challenges of a new school year.

Vocabulary of the Summer Olympics.list_brief_description:
The 2016 Olympic Games will begin this August in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Learn this list of 28 words so you can keep up with each sport from start to finish.
...

archery.word_example: There will be lake fishing, kayaking,  archery and shooting sports, guided by expert instructors.
archery.word_definition: the sport of shooting arrows with a bow

referee.word_example: “I thought he touched it with his hand. It was a difficult decision for the  referee.”
referee.word_definition: the official in a sport who is expected to ensure fair play

participant.word_example: He went to the club to for a meet and greet with some of the 336  participants at the outing.
participant.word_definition: a person who takes part in or is skilled at some game

equestrian.word_example: When horseback riding was the dominant mode of transportation,  equestrian shops were as common as fresh-pressed juice bars are today.
equestrian.word_definition: of or relating to or featuring horseback riding

synchronized.word_description: In the summer, there is synchronized swimming. In the winter, there is synchronized ice skating.
synchronized.word_example: And he delivered, doing some  synchronized moves with several pros that really did make an impression.

sportsmanship.word_example: The players are indulging in a handshake of  sportsmanship, which will, of course, ensure impeccable behaviours.
sportsmanship.word_definition: fairness and courtesy in following the rules of a game

endurance.word_example: In recent history, when the Finals end with a for-it-all final showdown, the games are more battles of  endurance than thrilling, free-flowing basketball.
endurance.word_definition: the power to withstand hardship or stress

venue.word_example: The performance transformed the sold-out  venue into a deafening celebration.
venue.word_definition: the scene of any event or action

opponent.word_example: Put another way, how could such groups find so many people willing to die for their causes, while their  opponents found so few?
opponent.word_definition: a contestant that you are matched against

stamina.word_example: Rugby is far more satisfying and fun, and it takes a lot more  stamina.

competitor.word_example: In the “weight over the bar” event,  competitors can use only one hand to toss a 56-pound weight over a horizontal bar.
competitor.word_definition: the contestant you hope to defeat

victory.word_example: The 18-time Olympic champion can punch his ticket to Rio on Wednesday with a  victory in the 200 fly final.
victory.word_definition: a successful ending of a struggle or contest

spectator.word_example: Despite bad weather, 263,500  spectators attended the race weekend.
spectator.word_definition: a close observer; someone who looks at something

preliminary.word_example: The 18-time Olympic champion advanced to the semifinals of the 200-meter butterfly at the U.S. swimming trials Tuesday with the fastest time in the  preliminaries.
preliminary.word_definition: a minor match preceding the main event

contestant.word_example: But he passed only four  contestants down the lane of the 1 1/4-mile course for his poorest placement in seven starts.
contestant.word_definition: a person who participates in competitions

nationality.word_example: Married to an Albanian woman, he acquired Albanian  nationality last year.
nationality.word_definition: the status of belonging to a particular country

vault.word_example: Then she felt a twinge in her knee while landing a  vault during practice in early April.
vault.word_definition: the act of jumping over an obstacle

pommel.word_example: Jesse won gold in parallel bars, rings, vaulting table and  pommel horse, silver in the high bar and bronze in floor exercise.
pommel.word_definition: a handgrip that a gymnast uses when performing exercises

riposte.word_example: It was the perfect  riposte to anyone doubting his technique against the short ball and set the tone for a magnificent attacking century.
riposte.word_definition: a counterattack made immediately after successfully parrying

substitute.word_example: He was then dropped against Albania, coming on as a  substitute in the second half.
substitute.word_definition: an athlete who plays when a starter on the team is replaced

sponsor.word_example: Now, she's a professional athlete, albeit still oozing charisma, and  sponsors are betting big bucks on her to succeed again.
sponsor.word_definition: someone who supports or champions something

Vocabulary of the Summer Olympics.list_detailed_description: The 2016 Olympic Games will begin this August in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Learn this list of 28 words so you can keep up with each sport from start to finish.

Words from the 4th of July Songbook.list_brief_description: There are so many things about the 4th of July that are familiar — the flags, the fireworks, the barbecues and the patriotic songs we all know (or can flub ou...

dandy.word_description: A man concerned with his appearance, a dandy, would want to be up on the latest trends-he has to be a good dancer, and a decent romancer.
dandy.word_definition: a man who is much concerned with his dress and appearance

acquaintance.word_definition: personal knowledge or information about someone or something

emblem.word_description: You’re a Grand Old Flag is clear about its intentions as a song. It is an ode to the flag itself, which is an emblem &mdash a symbol standing for something else, in this case, the United States of America. The word dates from the 1580s.  Emblem derives from when the word referred to work done on a ship merely for decoration. It was not until the 18th century that  emblem came to refer to decorations acting to signify something else — to function as a symbol.
emblem.word_definition: a visible symbol representing an abstract idea

majesty.word_description: Majesty comes ultimately from Latin  magnus, meaning “great, large, abundant, of considerable value and strong”. Of course,  majesty is usually a word used to describe a ruler with a title, like king or queen, and it is telling that in a land without a monarchy, this honor is bestowed on the bounty of nature that can be found within the USA.

hail.word_description: Hail is an interjection of cheer and welcome dating back to the 1200s, but it is particularly appropriate used in this context, when the outcome of a battle is uncertain. It is an Old English shortening of  wæs hæil, “be healthy” “be whole.” In other words, it is a wish, a kind of prayer, that things turn out alright.
hail.word_example: O say can you see, by the dawn's early light,

grace.word_description: Grace is defined as “love” or “compassion,” the “pardon, and favor” especially of a divine presence. The author of the poem on which the song is based, Katharine Lee Bates, is so overcome by looking at Pike’s Peak in Colorado (which is said to look purple, hence “purple mountains majesties”) that she follows the description of the beauty by invoking the grace of God.
grace.word_definition: a disposition to kindness and compassion

rampart.word_example: O say can you see, by the dawn's early light,
rampart.word_definition: an embankment built around a space for defensive purposes

glare.word_example: O say can you see, by the dawn's early light,

gallantly.word_description: Gallantly, a word Francis Scott Key uses to describe the way the flags streamed, means “heroically” or “bravely” and is about the soldiers doing battle, who are metaphorically represented by the flag.
gallantly.word_example: O say can you see, by the dawn's early light,
gallantly.word_definition: in a heroic or brave manner

twilight.word_example: O say can you see, by the dawn's early light,
twilight.word_definition: the time of day immediately following sunset

perilous.word_example: O say can you see, by the dawn's early light,

Words from the 4th of July Songbook.list_detailed_description: There are so many things about the 4th of July that are familiar — the flags, the fireworks, the barbecues and the patriotic songs we all know (or can flub our way through) the first verse to. But how well do we really know those songs, and what do those words mean? Here are 20 vocabulary words from four classic patriotic songs:

Ides, Eon, Epoch, and Era: Time-related.list_brief_description: Beware the ides of March, and other obscure time-related words that you only see once in a blue moon. Learn these terms in a fortnight (perhaps less?), and ushe...

jubilee.word_description: A jubilee is an anniversary: usually the fiftieth anniversary. It’s a celebratory, joyous, wake-the-neighbors kind of word. Originally, this was a Jewish term that vividly described scenes of Hebrew slaves being freed, trumpets blasting across the land. These days, the word is far less specific, meaning pretty much any sort of celebration.
jubilee.word_example: Large-scale  jubilee celebrations are expected to be reserved for the Platinum  Jubilee in 2022, when the monarch will mark 70 years.
jubilee.word_definition: a special anniversary or the celebration of it

coeval.word_example: It was one of the first two inland settlements of the colony, being  coeval with Concord.

chronological.word_example: It would allow doctors to search a patient's entire medical history in  chronological order before they arrived at their bedside.
chronological.word_definition: relating to or arranged according to temporal order

biennial.word_example: His administration did not hold a routine press briefing of the governor’s last  biennial budget, which was released late Friday.

eternal.word_example: But then again, a hospital is a place where hope reliably springs  eternal.

perpetual.word_example: She walked in  perpetual fear of tripping and falling, of breaking an ankle stepping into a pothole.

advent.word_example: Technology also plays a huge role in the story - particularly with the  advent of radio in the 1920s.

eon.word_description: This is a length of time so long it’s impossible to fathom. The meaning of  eon, a word that’s been found since the 1500s, has been relatively consistent, meaning either an endless, eternity-type period of time or a geological period, which is pretty long too, involving billions of years. You’re most likely to see this word in exaggerations such as “You’ve been yammering about Batman for eons” or “It’s been eons since I went for Indian food. What’s wrong with me?”
eon.word_example: The skull was crushed  eons ago during the fossilization process.
eon.word_definition: the longest unit of geological time

biannual.word_example: Our  biannual clock-tuning is a slip of the mask, a glitch in the matrix that reminds us that clock time is always artificial and arbitrary.
biannual.word_definition: occurring or payable twice each year

interval.word_example: The action is repeated at two-hour  intervals throughout the day and evening.
interval.word_definition: a definite length of time marked off by two instants

epoch.word_description: Not to be confused with  epic, which is both a long narrative poem and an adjective which describes something surpassing the ordinary,  epoch is a period of time — geologic, historical, or cultural — marked by certain characteristics.
epoch.word_example: Epochs demarcate time on the order of a few million years.
epoch.word_definition: a period marked by distinctive character

halcyon.word_description: Just as people look wistfully back on days of yore, they yearn for their halcyon days, which are basically the good old days when everything was chocolate cake, everywhere and all the time. This word was originally the name of a Greek bird.
halcyon.word_example: They spend their time sailing, playing tennis, and sometimes recalling the  halcyon days of crossing the moors behind packs of beagles to hunt down rabbits.

millennium.word_description: This word for a thousand years was heard quite frequently about 17 years ago, as we shifted from one millennium to another. The original meaning of this word, much like our system of years, was distinctly Christian: it referred to a foretold 1000 years in which Christ would reign on earth, according to the Book of Revelations. As words tend to do, this one changed in meaning, coming to refer to any 1000-year period.
millennium.word_example: The wreck confirms that sea-based commerce between China and West Asia was thriving more than a  millennium ago.

era.word_example: While the novel suffers at times from its adolescent tone, Jessica is a worthy heroine for our  era.
era.word_definition: a major division of geological time

fortnight.word_description: This term meaning two weeks has been around a little longer than that, dating from the days of Old English. If you want to impress a time traveler from the days of yore, this is a great word to use. An even rarer old term,  sennight, means one week.
fortnight.word_example: The maximum penalty will be a fine or up to a  fortnight in police custody.
fortnight.word_definition: a period of fourteen consecutive days

contemporaneous.word_description: This is a word for things that happen at the same time: if you spill apple cider on your favorite shirt while Taylor Swift is hunting rabbits in an underground maze thousands of miles beneath the Earth’s surface, those events were contemporaneous. If you teach your cat to walk on a leash, and then sometime later the moon is revealed as a spy satellite for Martians, those events were non-contemporaneous. And also weird, but that’s another matter.
contemporaneous.word_example: March Madness is about to begin, and Twitter will be stuffed full of  contemporaneous commentary about the games being played.
contemporaneous.word_definition: occurring in the same period of time

phase.word_example: Aid groups warned on Friday that the most dangerous  phase of the offensive was about to begin.
phase.word_definition: any distinct time period in a sequence of events

yore.word_description: Speaking of yore, this is an old-fashioned word for old-fashioned times. “The days of yore” are the bygone, long-lost, age-old times that hardly anyone can remember but everyone loves to glorify.
yore.word_example: It is a long way from the old groovy hippie days of  yore.

perennial.word_example: One of the  perennial questions for rock fans is which is the most important year in its history?

devoted.word_example: Feel like that question has been posed

persona.word_definition: a personal facade that one presents to the world

redemption.word_definition: the act of delivering from sin or saving from evil
redemption.word_example: True love breathes salvation back into

aqueduct.word_definition: a conduit that carries water over a valley
aqueduct.word_example: Yeah, I keep runnin', jump in the

pose.word_example: Feel like that question has been  posed

crave.word_definition: have an appetite or great desire for
crave.word_example: She too smart to  crave material things

remedy.word_definition: a medicine or therapy that cures disease or relieves pain
remedy.word_example: True love breathes salvation back into

cavalier.word_definition: given to haughty disregard of others

wade.word_example: I'ma  wade, I'ma wave through the

drought.word_example: You and me would stop this love

salvation.word_definition: rescuing or protecting someone or something from harm
salvation.word_example: True love breathes  salvation back into

reckless.word_definition: marked by defiant disregard for danger or consequences
reckless.word_example: I'm so  reckless when I rock my

Tax Day Words.list_brief_description: Tax Day, April 15th, is the second most dreaded day of the year—next to Doomsday. The language of taxation runs all over the financial map, describing the wea...

code.word_description: This slang term for money is silly and awesome.
code.word_example: The White House later said it would lead the role in reforming the U.S. tax  code, eyeing an August deadline.
code.word_definition: a set of rules or principles or laws

exemption.word_description: An exemption is an exception: official permission to not do something you would normally have to do. People can get exemptions from jury duty, military service, and who knows what else; I’m a columnist, not a lawyer. In tax terms, an exemption creates a tax-free bubble around income or purchases.
exemption.word_example: Other cases deal with a variety of issues including alleged breach of contract and tax  exemptions.
exemption.word_definition: deduction allowed to a taxpayer because of his or her status

wealth.word_description: You’ve probably heard rich folks described as  wealthy: that means they have  wealth. At minimum, this suggests what is technically referred to as “loads of dough.”
wealth.word_example: Many people would rather pull stakes and move to an entirely different place than share their  wealth with "others."
wealth.word_definition: the state of being rich and affluent

government.word_description: People complain a lot about the government on Tax Day. Well, they do that on all other days too, but complaints reach a peak on April 15 because the government collects those taxes.
government.word_example: Those estimates all trace back an October 2016 report by the  Government Accountability Office.
government.word_definition: study of the authority of states and other political units

filthy.word_description: Words for repellent things and words for enormous things have a tendency to overlap, and that’s how  filthy came to describe the rich: specifically, people who have so much money it’s outrageous and obscene.
filthy.word_example: Partly, it seems, the Chinese corporate tourists are beguiled by the Valley’s dreamlike promises of changing the world and growing  filthy rich almost overnight.

deduction.word_description: This word is sweet music to the ears of taxpayers: when you have a deduction, you can trim your taxable income, which means fewer dollars owed and ulcers grown.
deduction.word_example: Eliminating tax  deductions and credits to pay for lower tax rates is a strategy that sends economists’ hearts aflutter.
deduction.word_definition: a decrease in the gross amount on which a tax is calculated

accountant.word_description: Accountants keep financial records for businesses, individuals, and the secret worldwide Illuminati, probably. Many accountants also do people’s taxes. Accountants, as the name implies, keep track of  accounts. You might have a checking account and savings account, but businesses have all sorts of accounts related to equipment, training, food, advertising, etc. They might even have a  Swiss bank account—a term often used in jokes to indicate someone is hiding money from the feds.
accountant.word_example: “Farmers wear a lot of hats,” Hearst said, explaining many farmers are their own managers,  accountants and marketing team, along with the duties of farming.
accountant.word_definition: someone who maintains and audits financial records

dough.word_description: Dough is an old word for the pasty stuff, made of flour or meal that gets molded and baked into bread. But since the mid-1800s, dough has also meant  moolah.
dough.word_example: If she could scale and control prices, she come make some real  dough.

estimate.word_description: If you’re a freelancer like myself, most of your jobs don’t take out any taxes. That gives you two choices: every April, pay the federal government a zillion dollars, including several pounds of flesh. The better option is to make  estimated payments four times a year. To do that, you need to  estimate how much you should pay. Estimating isn’t like guessing: it’s more like measuring, though not quite that exact.
estimate.word_example: Even so, Tesla now trades at some 28 times  estimated earnings in 2020.

destitute.word_description: Lots of people have money problems: but only the truly poor are destitute. To be destitute is to have no money for food, shelter, or anything else. This has also been a word for people lacking more than money: you can destitute of friends, companionship, hope, and/or freedom. Many people are. Now I’m depressed. Let’s just move on.
destitute.word_example: Destitute and desperate, she started stealing diapers, food and toys.
destitute.word_definition: poor enough to need help from others

loophole.word_example: Tax law is riddled with  loopholes embedded in the economy and defended by beneficiaries.
loophole.word_definition: an ambiguity that makes it possible to evade an obligation

Tax Day Words.list_detailed_description: Tax Day, April 15th, is the second most dreaded day of the year—next to Doomsday. The language of taxation runs all over the financial map, describing the wealthy, the disadvantaged, and the ungodly process of paying taxes. Here are some words you're likely to hear in relation to this stressful day, which can be—pardon the expression—quite taxing. Read the full article:

Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Heart's Club Band T.list_brief_description: June of 2017 marks the 50th anniversary of one of The Beatles' greatest albums, Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Heart’s Club Band. The imagery and expressions on Sgt. ...

glimpse.word_example: We were talking about the space between us all

splendid.word_example: The band begin at ten to six when mr. K. performs his tricks
splendid.word_definition: very good; of the highest quality

clutch.word_example: Wedn'sday morning at five o'clock as the day begins,

drift.word_example: Follow her down to a bridge by a fountain
drift.word_definition: wander from a direct course or at random

discreet.word_description: Discreetly means “with self restraint, wisely” and is the exact opposite of how the narrator of the song is feeling on the inside — in his head, he’s already captured her heart, but in real life, they don’t know each other, so he has started slowly, simply asking her to tea. No one can stop you from imagining an entire future with women in crisp uniforms, but please act with wise restraint when asking them on dates. Act discreetly!
discreet.word_definition: marked by prudence or modesty and wise self-restraint

roam.word_example: Going to work don't want to go, feeling low down.
roam.word_definition: move about aimlessly or without any destination

mend.word_example: I could be handy  mending a fuse
mend.word_definition: restore by putting together what is torn or broken

porter.word_example: Picture yourself on a train in a station
porter.word_definition: a person employed to carry luggage and supplies

kaleidoscope.word_description: A kaleidoscope is a tubular toy filled with mirrors and colorful materials that you hold to your eye and turn to create ever changing patterns. Its inventor put together some Greek elements to capture the essence of his entertaining toy,  kalos, “beautiful” +  eidos, “shape” combined with the  -scope from telescope.
kaleidoscope.word_example: Picture yourself in a boat on a river
kaleidoscope.word_definition: an optical toy in a tube

Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Heart's Club Band T.list_detailed_description: June of 2017 marks the 50th anniversary of one of The Beatles' greatest albums, Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Heart’s Club Band. The imagery and expressions on Sgt. Pepper's yielded some of the most listenable music and interesting lyrics in the history of pop music. Here are 17 vocabulary words drawn from Sgt. Pepper's.

Beam Me Up: Talking About Star Trek.list_brief_description: Every time a new adaptation of Star Trek is released, there's plenty of buzz about what is one of the most enduring and iconic science fiction franchises. Rathe...

prime.word_definition: of or relating to the first or originating agent
prime.word_description: Anything prime is the best or highest example something. In Star Trek, the prime directive states that Starfleet ships shouldn’t be meddling in other planet’s cultures just because they feel like it or think they know better.
prime.word_example: For the uninitiated, the  prime directive was a Star Trek philosophy which prohibited members of the United Federation of Planets from interfering with the internal development of alien civilizations. In other words, it was a basic understanding that one civilization or race wouldn’t screw with the development of another.

trek.word_example: The writer and director was also responsible for another successful reboot in the form of the recent Star  Trek series.

enterprise.word_example: While transporting two passengers to their home planet, the  Enterprise team loses its way.

hybrid.word_description: A hybrid combines two things: a restaurant could be a hybrid of Mexican and Chinese food, while a hybrid car runs on both gas and electric. Animal hybrids include the mule (the offspring of a donkey and horse). Mixed dog breeds could also be called hybrids, such as the labradoodle (Labrador and poodle) and puggle (pug and beagle). Mr. Spock is often referred to as a hybrid because his father is a Vulcan and his mother is an Earthling.
hybrid.word_example: Mr. Spock is one of the world's most loved and most enduring sci-fi characters. A green-blooded, human-Vulcan  hybrid, he was Captain Kirk's loyal aide, and his conscience, and second in command of the Star Ship Enterprise.

mission.word_definition: an operation that is assigned by a higher headquarters
mission.word_description: The opening lines of Star Trek’s original series are famous: “Space, the final frontier. These are the voyages of the starship Enterprise. Its five-year mission: to explore strange new worlds, to seek out new life and new civilizations, to boldly go where no man has gone before." A mission is a purpose and goal: a reason for doing something. You could say you’re on a mission to find the perfect cheeseburger. People on a religious mission are dedicated to helping (and possibly converting) people.
mission.word_example: The ship, and its crew, are mysterious hybrids, but with just 10 days to go before the CBS All Access debut of the new show — which is actually a prequel that takes place in a universe about a decade before the five-year  mission at the heart of the original series — producers have revealed a few new secrets behind the warship's design.

warp.word_definition: bend or twist out of shape
warp.word_example: When Jean-Luc Picard was in command of the starship Enterprise, characters from the various TV series Star Trek: The Next Generation, Deep Space Nine, and even Voyager could move to the silver screen at  warp speed.

crystal.word_definition: a rock with regularly repeating internal structure
crystal.word_description: Dilithium crystals power the Enterprise, but only the dilithium part is made-up. Crystals are real solids found in nature that have geometrical patterns described as
crystal.word_example: Koolmees documented the involved project on his K-Money Industries website. Dilithium, the  crystal that powers Federation starships, is stubbornly fictional, so Koolmees build the dilithium chamber to hold his home server instead.

neutral.word_description: To be neutral is to not have a side: neutral parties aren’t rooting for anyone, whether in politics, war, or sports. In Star Trek, the Neutral Zone is an area of space not controlled by the Federation, Klingons, or Romulans.
neutral.word_example: The Kobayashi Maru fake-out massacre that opens the film still kills an audience. While Captain Spock (Leonard Nimoy) observes from his science station, Captain-in-training Saavik (Kirstie Alley) attempts to navigate a  Neutral Zone rescue mission with catastrophic political Klingon consequences.

logic.word_definition: the branch of philosophy that analyzes inference
logic.word_description: Logic is a specific type of reason that can be demonstrated or proven. Mr. Spock, like other Vulcans, is devoted to logic, as opposed to emotion.
logic.word_example: Originally a fleet was a group of ships in the Navy, but since Star Trek’s space forces are modeled on naval tradition, words like fleet (and first officer) were borrowed by writers.

fleet.word_definition: group of aircraft operating under the same ownership
fleet.word_description: Originally a fleet was a group of ships in the navy, but since Star Trek’s space forces are modeled on naval tradition, words like
fleet.word_example: When the Enterprise hosts an officer from the Klingon  fleet, the crew faces an instant culture-clash. Worf is sensitive to other Klingons perceiving him as weak or “too human,” but the situation quickly moves beyond mere social awkwardness.

torpedo.word_definition: a long cylindrical self-propelled underwater projectile
torpedo.word_description: By the 1700s, the word had gained its more contemporary meaning: as a type of explosive, in the shape of a cigar, launched from a submarine.
torpedo.word_example: In ‘Star Trek,’ photon  torpedoes were matter-antimatter weapons on starships. In real life, photons are microscopic particles of light that have a wide range of scientific applications from manufacturing to medicine to communication.

regulation.word_definition: the act of bringing to uniformity
regulation.word_description: Regulations are rules, especially specific rules for a particular group or organization. Captain Kirk is well-known for flouting Starfleet regulations.
regulation.word_example: The appearance of "an object of unknown origin" seems to kickstart the events of Star Trek: Discovery. This object is found "on the edge of Federation space," and it seems that the USS Shenzou is venturing a little further than Starfleet  regulations would usually allow.

stun.word_definition: make senseless or dizzy by or as if by a blow
stun.word_description: This word comes from a very specific Star Trek phrase that became a part of popular culture: “Set phasers to stun!” This was actually a decent thing to do, since the alternative was setting them to kill. If a Starfleet officer hit someone with a phaser set on stun, it knocked them unconscious, similar to how a linebacker can stun a quarterback. People are also stunned by bad or shocking news. To be stunned is to be knocked out: literally or metaphorically.
stun.word_example: Regardless of whether these weapons are set to  stun, blast aliens, or wrangle ghosts, the question is this: Are zap-guns plausible?

galaxy.word_description: The universe is everything that exists. A solar system is a group of planets orbiting a sun, just like Earth and Mars and Jupiter and the rest orbit our little sun, or Sunny, as I like to call her. The unit in-between is the galaxy: a galaxy is made up of many solar systems. As best I can tell, the adventures of Star Trek take place all or mostly within our galaxy, the Milky Way.
galaxy.word_example: The two soon find that they have passed through a wormhole that has deposited them on the other side of the  galaxy.

engineer.word_definition: a person who uses scientific knowledge to solve problems
engineer.word_description: Engineers design and build many things, but in Star Trek, the engineer has a more literal job: taking care of the engines.
engineer.word_example: For María Regina Apodaca Moreno, 22, of all the crew members of the starship Enterprise it was chief  engineer Scotty who was her inspiration.

Beam Me Up: Talking About Star Trek.list_detailed_description: Every time a new adaptation of Star Trek is released, there's plenty of buzz about what is one of the most enduring and iconic science fiction franchises. Rather than a glossary of Klingon terms, we've rounded up some of the more relevant English terms that get bandied about when there's a Star Trek media frenzy.

Albert Einstein.list_brief_description: Calling all budding geniuses! Don't let inertia stop you from learning these words related to physicist Albert Einstein and his work. Best known for developing ...

theory.word_definition: a well-substantiated explanation of some aspect of the world
theory.word_example: Albert Einstein’s  theory of general relativity was still being met with skepticism.

refugee.word_definition: an exile who flees for safety
refugee.word_example: This letter shows that Einstein also lobbied on behalf of the larger group of  refugees, leveraging his public profile to ask the Roosevelts to work harder to overcome red tape and quotas that impeded emigration.

relativity.word_definition: the theory that space and time are not absolute concepts
relativity.word_example: In the early 20th century, Albert Einstein’s new and controversial theory of  relativity predicted that gravity would cause light to bend.

physicist.word_definition: a scientist trained in the science of matter and energy
physicist.word_example: In the 1920s, while living in Berlin, the  physicist collaborated with Hungarian graduate assistant Leo Szilárd to develop and patent an energy-efficient fridge.

pacifism.word_definition: the belief that all disputes can be settled by arbitration
pacifism.word_example: And then there are the fleeting references to Einstein’s outspoken  pacifism, anti-fascism and support for civil rights — which put him under FBI scrutiny.

inertia.word_definition: the tendency of something to stay in rest or motion
inertia.word_example: Mass can be considered as a measure of  inertia, or resistance to motion.

equation.word_definition: a mathematical statement that two expressions are the same
equation.word_example: Albert Einstein is perhaps most famous for introducing the world to the  equation E=mc2.

genius.word_definition: someone who has exceptional intellectual ability
genius.word_example: Albert Einstein is widely regarded as a  genius, but how did he get that way?

mass.word_definition: the property of a body that causes it to have weight
mass.word_example: In a book on special relativity, you might expect to meet Einstein's  mass–energy equivalence, E = mc2, close to the beginning.

theoretical.word_definition: concerned with hypotheses and not practical considerations
theoretical.word_example: Finding a particle-based description of gravity has obsessed  theoretical physicists since Einstein.

quantum.word_definition: the smallest discrete quantity of some physical property
quantum.word_example: He says it confirms that gravity interacts with  quantum fields in the manner indicated by Einstein’s theories of relativity.

physics.word_definition: the science of matter and energy and their interactions
physics.word_example: Einstein's work laid the foundation for modern  physics and cosmology, providing a perspective of space and time that is shaped by gravity.

energy.word_definition: the capacity of a physical system to do work
energy.word_example: His famous E = mc2 revealed a vast asymmetry in the cosmic relationship between matter and  energy.

Albert Einstein.list_detailed_description: Calling all budding geniuses! Don't let inertia stop you from learning these words related to physicist Albert Einstein and his work. Best known for developing the theory of relativity, Einstein is widely considered to be one of the greatest scientists of all time. If these words give you the momentum to learn more about physics, you can practice our introductory physics list
